After I finished streaming the emoji movie on Netflix yesterday, I guess It's not bad, nor good. I don't know why people criticize the movie before it is even released in theatersd I seen people in the comments say that they are not gonna watch it because it is going to be "cringey" or "bad" or "that no one would want to watch it but young kids who actually want to see the movie." etc etc. I had to agree with everyone else here because of their non constructive criticism. At school everyone was talking about how trash it is and stuff. Well, that is what 2 of my friends say anyways. And for the whole school days we sometimes talk about why the movie is garbage and how the characters too atrocious (referring to the 3rd Dimensional smileys with arms and legs.) I said that I was gonna watch it after it's launch. and never did. For 3 years. Till in 2020, I thought that I was going to watch said movie title on Netflix. My sister has her subscription of Netflix for the both of us so it would be very easy to get ahold with the movie. So I actually watched it. At first I thought it was going to be worse just like the Internet thought but... In my opinion AGAIN, I don't love it... I don't hate it either... It's just In... The middle. Ok done.

Like the movie's main character, the whole story line was "meh" and left me and my entire family feeling like we wasted our time and money. It's hard to imagine a movie this bad coming out at this point of time. I can see how this would be OK if a group of college students made it, but this is by Sony Pictures. I hold those guys to higher standards and they failed us. They failed us so bad, they should refund me my money.

I don't understand why the score is so low. Yes, it's not the movie of the century and yes there's advertising in it but the animation is good and the main character is likable. The plot is pretty straight forward, in the emoji world every emoji have to keep his one face on at all times but one emoji just can do it and he goes on a quest to fix himself so he can be like everybody else.
I think it is mostly for kids but I don't see a reason why the whole family couldn't watch it together.
I guess, if you're looking for something extraordinary or super clever, then it's probably not for you but if you just want to watch a fun animated movie with your kids, there's no reason not to enjoy it.

I was forced to watch it with my siblings and I hated every minute of it, I came out of the cinema just to realize that I wasted 1hr 30 minutes of my life watching this garbage.It is one of the most unoriginal movies I have ever seen in my entire life, its setting and theme are literally derived from films like Wreck-It Ralph, Inside Out and The Lego Movie.I mean Jailbreak, is literally a copy-paste of Lucy from the lego movie, and Gene is derived from Ralph in Wreck-It Ralph and Emmet from the Lego Movie, and HI-5 who is meant to be funny sidekick is more obnoxious than funny, I mean come on, his jokes are literally the most unfunniest anyone would ever think of, even children would not laugh at.Even the animation is the laziest I have seen especially considering that this was released in 2017, I mean Pixar films of the 1990s (Toy Story, A Bug's Life & Toy Story 2) were better animated than this piece of trash.One last thing, I still do not understand how can a loving God give people such a horrendous idea for a film and the ability to even make and release it.Please, for the love of all that is holy, DO NOT WATCH THIS FILM, I literally lost 10% of my braincells this watching and wasted 1hr 30min of my life and even questioned the existence of God after realising that he would let a film this bad go into theaters.

Let's get this out of the way: The Emoji Movie is by no means a good movie. In many ways, it suffers from the same problem as the Pirates of the Caribbean sequels. The graphics are beautiful, and the voice acting is spectacular. The music isn't the best, but it's still decent. They got great animators, actors, and composers to make this movie. So why was it so bad? In a word, the writers. I don't know what the people who scripted this thing were thinking. The plot is just so terrible, there are no words. The main issue with the plot is how utterly cliche it is. If you think about it, this movie is basically the Lego Movie, but with all the minifigures replaced by emojis. The Lego movie really was a good movie, but this movie stole it's plot, removed all the exciting scenes, severely diluted the antagonist, and basically turned it into garbage.Occasionally, the movie will throw in a good joke. Some of them are actually pretty funny and witty. That's the main upside. If nothing else, it will occasionally make you laugh.But all of that aside, as a hardcore fan of Michael Jackson, there is one element of this movie that I do find offensive: Hi-Five claiming he can dance as good as "Michael" and putting on a Smooth Criminal Style fedora, then immediately proceeding to dance terribly. As a fan of Michael Jackson, I hate this scene for that one reason.
Not sure why there are so many haters for this film. It's great! And it's funny! I love watching it especially with my kids. Great message!

I really did like the film, but there were times where it was a bit elongated. Some people might not be able to relate but when your job revolves around social media you kinda get a better connection with the characters.

This movie is simply amazing! I loved every part of it! Especially the poop jokes!Just kidding. The whole movie is a great big pile of Patrick Stewart. When I wasn't cringing . . . . Oh, wait, I cringed through the entire movie. I mean, the plot revolves around "meh". That is very risky, and they blew it. Do not watch this movie. Not in the theaters, not on redbox, not even on Netflix (where I saw it). It wastes time, money, or both.

Contrary to many unbelievable online reviews, this movie is quite trash. If, in the future, the human race were to look back at our past achievements and judge whether or not we were on the right track, they'd most likely assume we were in the dark ages again, only this time with emojis.
This movie has no merit, no redeeming qualities and no enjoyment to be had while watching it. This 90 minute endurance test serves only as product placement and an advertisement. If you went to the theatre to watch this movie, you'd probably have a hard time telling the difference between the pre-movie ads and the movie itself. That would also mean that you paid for that experience, and for that you have my sympathy. 
They actually somehow got Sir Patrick Stewart to voice a role in this movie, and his character was, quite literally, poop. Delivering some of the laziest poop jokes that Hollywood has ever written, I guess even Picard needs the money. This movie is absolute trash, not even worthy of being taken into a tip or a landfill, just atomically disassemble the entire thing and launch it into space where some alien colony will find it and eradicate it with lasers. 
The Emoji Movie made 217.8 Million dollars at the box office with a budget of 50 million dollars. Economists suspect that this movie will serve as a catalyst for another worldwide economic crash, and I for one welcome it.
This movie actually won awards and were nominated for some others, some of which were more deserving. It won worst picture, worst director, worst screen combo and worst screenplay. It was also nominated for the Black Reel Awards, Movieguide Awards and Kids' Choice Awards, for whatever value that's worth. 
I don't think I can actually get away with simply saying that this movie is bad, everyone knows it. You know it, I know it, the people that made this movie know it and even the people that were paid to give these movies good reviews especially know it. Things need to change. We need to riot. We need to start a new Hollywood revolution. Anyone that is listening needs to heed my call. We need to tell people that we will not stand for this anymore. WE. WANT. FREEDOM.

Everyone keeps saying this movie is terrible but it's not that bad. Certainly it is not the 41st worst movie ever...I think anyone will admit that it's not exactly polished; a lot of the jokes are too in-your-face, there's an over abundance of puns and a lot of the dialogue is heavy and awkward but that doesn't mean it isn't fun.The inspiration apparently came from toy story and continues a tradition of compiling real pop culture references that we saw in Roger Rabbit, Food Fight and Wreck It Ralph though the movies actual narrative seems most indebted to the Lego movie with its themes of conformism and creativity of expression.I like the message even if it is kind of ham fisted, both our protagonist Gene and the female lead Jailbreak are likeable even if JailBreak is blatantly just Wyldestyle from the Lego Movie and James Cordon's High comic relief as High Five is maybe kind of annoying but that's more due to lame jokes than any intrinsic problem. I found the antagonist actually pretty creepy, as are all perpetually happy people.Ultimately I came away feeling warmly about the movie for it's rich, distinctive world, positive message and how it embodies an aspect of its time while tying it to a universal them even if it's not exactly subtle about it.

Honestly, this movie is probably the worst I've ever seen. The whole idea is creative and could've been such an amazing movie but it was lacking a lot of things, like the plot and dialogue. The visuals, characters and setting was terrific. It was visually appealing and all the apps and emojis were very imaginative and well done, but the dialogue was cringe and the plot was confusing. A lot of it didn't make sense, and the good parts of the movie sadly don't make up for the bad. I don't think this is a suitable movie for young kids as it involves social media and a lot of other things that only teens would understand but it is a pretty lame movie for older kids and adults. Don't waste your time and money on it!

If you want to see an amazing crime-drama, "The Emoji Movie" is for you. It contains a dazzling story, a insanely beautiful musical score, and well developed characters. I'd reccomend this movie if you like The Godfather and it's sequels. Though when you compare the Godfather and Emoji Movie, the God Father almost seems like a shameless rip off, yet it came first. I would show it to my kids if I had some.

0.5/4...And yes I saw it...well, kind of. Half of it at least. This could very well be the worst movie of 2017. It is a movie that only exists due to being in a state of obvious parody. It possesses no merit of its own, it's highly chichÃ©d, and it lacks any kind of originality.The flaws of this movie are so incredibly abundant, that it would take forever to jot them all down. Among the first that come to mind: the bad apple is obvious from the start. It feels political (just look at the emojis confirmed to their communist-like society). There is no emotional connection to any character whatsoever...only whimsical spikes of interest here and there. The script is bland and at times cringy. There is no emotional connection BETWEEN the characters (this is a problem because emojis represent...ah-hem...emotions) and to top it off, it feels second-hand in a very sour way.This movie is a BOMB as far as quality, but I think a 0.5/4 will suffice due to the fun I had laughing at it. It really makes you wonder how stinkers like this makes it past the drawing board.

Not worth anything,let alone your money. Go buy a Pixar film and have actual JOY in watching it.

The universal panning of The Emoji Movie (2017) is not deserved nor is it the worst movie of the year. It is easy to dismiss an animated film that satirises how humans communicate. However, it does raise serious issues; so if you are not interested in hearing a defence of the film, stop reading now.There are a number of levels at which The Emoji Movie can be read. If you expect conventional narrative logic, characterisation, emotional impact, clever script or technical originality, you will inevitably be disappointed. But if you are looking for an imaginative take on today's mass communication culture, it is an interesting film. The animated story unfolds inside the nano-world of a smartphone, amongst the apps populated by emoji. We see 'life' from the viewpoint of Gene who, on his first day in the emoji directory, is deemed dysfunctional because he shows more expression than allowed by his single-dimension 'meh' persona. When the phone-owning teenager selects Gene to send to his girlfriend it causes communication chaos in both human and smartphone worlds. Gene becomes a doomed emoji and must flee Textopolis in search of reprogramming, passing through firewalls and big-name apps like Instagram, Spotify and Twitter. He teams up with another obsolete emoji called Hi 5 and a love interest named Jailbreak, all with deadly bots in hot pursuit while the trio flee for safety in the Cloud. Doomsday approaches when the teenager decides to wipe his phone.OK, OK; you were warned that it is not a conventional film. So, what's the point? One clue is the classroom teacher who explains to cell phone-dependent students that human communication was first recorded using ancient hieroglyphics, a pictographic language similar to an emoji directory. Despite the evolution of written communication over millennia, the use of single-meaning pictographic symbols has exploded. Is this the way of the future? While the film does not answer this question, it does offer an imaginative look into the world of smartphone communication. There is a social class system that groups emoji into favourites, ordinary, and rarely used, and the favourites rule the world with popular one-dimensional messages. Ambivalent or unpopular emoji are publicly persecuted and the trash is the ghetto of the unwanted. The Smiley emoji was the first ever made and it now exerts totalitarian control through a smile that appears happy but can also mask sinister intent. Gender politics rules the emoji and tomboy Jailbreak is really a princess in disguise who is desperately trying to avoid being treated like a girl. In other words, the emoji domain is a perfect mirror of the human world.Nobody is arguing that this is a great film, but it is not a disaster. Decades from now it will be dug up and studied as a whimsical cultural artefact that portrays the imagined relationship between humanity and digital communication. Researchers will ask why hieroglyphics returned as a universal language and why humans came to rely on homogenised icons to convey meaning. If a movie can change the way you see things then it is worthwhile. This writer will never look at emoji in the same way again.

This movie had everything wrong. The story was awful, the characters were awful, and the concept completely is stupid. The movie shouldn't exist and the film felt like it led to nowhere. The ending was also unsatisfying. The jokes were corny and the character development leads to nowhere. This film is a monstrosity and can possibly be considered as the worst film in cinema history. The story was very unoriginal and the main villain had literally zero good motives become a villain in the first place. The plot-twist was awful as it led to nowhere. And there were some characters I wish I never met in my life.

We enjoyed watching this with the kids. My kids do love this movie and just keep watching it again and again. I'm shocked to learn it has so many awful reviews.
I cannot tell how good or bad the director of the movie is. But as a regular viewer who has small kids I can say it is quite entertaining and has some good things for little kids to learn, e.g. the main character, Gene, never leaves his friends behind and treats other members of his little emoji world with kindness no matter where they are in their social hierarchy. There are some interesting parallels with the real world as well: Gene has to be "meh" just like his parents who are "real pros". But instead he has a special ability to express many feelings at once which is treated as a "malfunction". One real story I can recall was about a kid who was incredibly talented dancer but could not focus in class and was nearly diagnosed with ADHD. We force kids and people in general into some sort of boxes and if they don't fit we consider it a disorder, a "malfunction", something that is not cool and should be fixed. This animation movie teaches little kids to be themselves and freely express themselves. Old idea but good nonetheless. This is great.
Whoever left extremely low ratings are probably sad people who cannot see anything good in life. Maybe the storyline wasn't great and the director wasn't good but there are good things about this anination and you cannot seriously be that displeased with just about everything.

I don't understand why everyone hates it so much. I just took it for what it was. It was a cute little story. I think people were expecting like Sausage Party which I couldn't even finish watching but I digress. I could watch this movie over again. It was kind of funny too.

The Emoji Movie is a worthless movie, unlike with movies that are probably worse, such as Doogal, I gained nothing from this. As bad as Doogal was, it is a movie that is fun to make fun of, I gained nothing from this film. The hand is also voiced by James Corden...
I take it back, change the 1/10 to a 0/10.
Nothing much too say. It's just that dumb and stupid.

The Emoji Movie 3 out of 10.
On all levels, it is a derivative of Wreck it Ralph and similar movies, replicating its premise, characters and themes, but executed without any nuance, design, substance or purpose. Where Wreck it Ralph is built on easy nostalgia-bait, the Emoji Movie seems to be a series of advertisements and product placements for Just Dance, Candy Crush and other apps. The Emoji Movie goes so far as to copy the twist regarding the female lead.The viewing experience is tiring as the comedy the movie strings its plot points together with is either knowingly lazy, or arrogantly naive. Humour in this movie is supposedly evident when high five throws up candy, monkeys say they are off to do "monkey business", or when Sir Patrick Stewart, the poop emoji says the words "stink", "duty", and -
Emoji 1: "Poop, youre so soft"
Sir Patrick Stewart as the poop emoji: "Not too soft I hope"The animation was basic, but not poor and distracting, so I guess that makes it boring. The world of 'Textopolis' and the phone was very basic and bare, even with all the bright colours on the screen. The music in this movie is played very obnoxiously, with half relevant dance songs such as, wake me up before you go-go, feel this moment and cheerleader to name a few. The icing on the cake to this movie is when it ends on an impromptu dance party, where everyone comes to accept the main character instantly, kinda like, but worse than, Despicable Me, Megamind and The LEGO Movie.
The relationships between the main three characters, the high five, the meh and jailbreak was more like 3 people hanging around each other, going to the same place, than high five and meh being friends and jailbreak any sort of love interest.
The slang made to relate to kids was also outdated by the time this movie came out. Having James Corden say shade, #blessed, lit and slay was really forced and unnecessary. I would also rather leave out the references in this movie that do not appeal to kids and are not enough to appeal to adults. The poop emoji pretending to be in star trek, the culture of internet trolls and the Trojan horse virus.
Kids deserve better than a cheap 86 minute distraction - see The Lego Movie or Wreck it Ralph instead, which both executed an 'it's okay to be yourself/different' story on a far greater level.

The IMDb user review guidelines suggests the use of English in expressing one own's thoughts and sentiments regarding the films/movies they have just seen is very much preferred in the reviews, although I've encountered some instances where people have kind of reverted back to speaking (or writing) in what is perhaps their own language, encountering phrases other than English every now and then is really no biggie. But now I have started to see that the cute innovation in e-communication, those emojis, have already crept into some submitted user reviews now (and I would state that I'm guilty of dropping ASCII ideograms/emoticons in reviews;) so I have no complaints there, that made me actually quite glad, but I'm kind of bothered about that at the same time. I find those things cute and consider it useful in spicing up whatever thought I'm trying to express, or lines of emojis such as this:ðŸ´ðŸ™ðŸ˜ðŸ‘ðŸŽ¯ðŸŽ¥is kind of struggle in squeezing enough brain juice to assemble that. A different language altogether. Perhaps I'm already to just too old for head to rewire new neural connections to be just as quick on my feet as the kids nowadays when it comes to those things. Talk about generational gap. Or I better leave such things for emojilogists to decipher. But using such for adornment, I find it quite fun, which kind of made me think of a modest proposal that maybe the IMDb crowd might one day consider. Perhaps by alloting a separate space in their website, or one could call it a shrine a corner in the webpage where people can sort of attribute what emoji would most describe their experience in having watched the film/movie in a more playful and colorful manner to complement the existing numeric rating (which is useful in sorting, or in giving a perspective of how a film stacks up against other films/movie made), those smiley face, crying face or poop emoji (that is if that would not be regarded as an unaccepable) will kind of give audience a chance to express their feelings or warning people of what they could expect about the film/movie. But perhaps imposing a three-emoji maximum would do for such a thing, which will then be displayed in a part of a the webpage, or a separate page with the frequently used ones ending up bigger than the lesser-used emojis, the same way some websites highlight the frequently used keywords by presenting them in bigger or slightly bigger fonts than the other lesser used ones. And those people who have difficulty in filling up the 50-character minimum requirement for posting reviews could knock themselves out in such a space, a place that will perhaps give a glance of what would turn out to be like one of those mini-Bruegel painting made of different emojis.I am aware that the GetSatisafaction message site is the more appropriate place for leaving such suggestions, but mine is not really a pressing matter. I'm just rambling and just compensating for having not much good to say about this movie.For a film that professes a moral that one should embrace their multidimentionality instead of hiding it, which is always a good thing, they sure used the wrong subject to proclaim that. Even though what ends up becoming as a well-intentioned, satisfactory CG-animated movie that's overflowing with kawaii appeal, and gives one a snapshot of tech/cyber landscape nowadays that perhaps in a few years time reach its obselescence, and a public bathroom scene with Gene and his parents which I find quite hysterical (one-layered humor where one doesn't need to wear a thinking caps to process it), and the variety of outstanding voice talents asked to participate in the film that includes comedian Steven Wright, a spot-on on being cast as Gene Meh's dad, all of that really was not enough to really redeem this movie. And I know it's easy to pick on an criticize a Razzie-awarded flick, but I just have to agree with them on that, because using a story of a rogue emoji, programmed to do a certain task and does something else, really just makes the main protagonist look more like an aberration.My rating: ðŸ¦Š-trot.

I've noticed this movie is getting a lot of hate ratings, and I wonder how many of the people that have rated it 1 have actually seen the movie. I have seen some movies that are worth rating a 1 before, but The Emoji Movie isn't quite that bad. This was the perfect movie for my 11 year old son, as he LOVED It! I was mildly amused. The movie wasn't awful, and it wasn't great.The movie is about a "meh" emoticon that gets sent (by the user) while making a different face. Apparently, it is unheard of to make the wrong face, so that gets him into a lot of trouble. He befriends an emoticon that used to be popular, but is hardly ever used now, and they seek out a emoticon defector/hacker to help Gene (Meh), become the meh he thinks he is supposed to be. I felt the movie had a good message about being yourself, although the character's aren't given much depth in the film.If you are considering taking your kids to this because you want something to do, but are unsure because of your reviews, you could take a chance on it. If you are broke and don't go to the movies very often, however, wait for video or streaming. Overall, it is a light, cheesy watch if there isn't anything else to see with the kids.

"The Emoji Movie" (2017) by Tony Leondis, while often criticized, holds a special place for many, including my daughters who genuinely enjoyed it! It's a vibrant, fast-paced adventure that brings the digital world to life with colorful animation and a positive message about embracing your true self, even if you're a "meh" emoji. The film's energy and simple humor resonated well, providing a fun and engaging experience for younger audiences. It's a lighthearted escape that proves entertainment can sometimes be found in the most unexpected places.

After seeing 'The Emoji Movie' I can effectively say that our veterans have it easy when it comes to Post Traumatic Stress Disorder, and yes that is a joke. If you think that joke is bad then you'd be right in thinking that I have about as much talent as everyone that worked on this movie. If your child comes and asks you to see this movie don't panic, just follow these simple steps: 1. Retrieve your shotgun 2. Put your child down. There's nothing else that can be done for them. I'm not going to write a real in depth review because this movie does not deserve it, so I'll just paste my notes here: The Good: nothing. Im serious, nothing is good in this movie. Some things are average or done somewhat-competently, like the overall animation, but nothing is actually above average or good.The Bad:-It's soulless -Has no pacing -Has no character development but still tries to force some anyways-Hates millennials, thinks we are dumb and self centered and callous. It also stereotypes us while preaching about not stereotyping women-literally forces feminism into the plot worse than any other film I have ever seen and tries to make princess emojis seem anti-women "I don't need a man to save me"a character says #truth literally beats you over the f*cking head about any and everything the boy wins the girl in the end by sending an emoji. This is not a joke or over simplification. This movie literally thinks we communicate solely through emojis -dialogue breaks down into 4 very obvious categories: 1. Sh*tty jokes 2. Forced social commentary 3. Forced and obvious character development 4. Forced and obvious statements meant to move the plot forward it plays the joke about the 'meh emojis saying emotional dialogue without emotions' throughout the whole f*cking film there is seriously no pacing in this film. Scenes just randomly end and go to other scenes for no rhyme or reason. This film basically has the bare minimum when it comes to plot, characters, and jokes This movie was made just for product placement and nothing else-THE BOY LITERALLY WRITES THE LYRICS TO "shine bright like a diamond" AS A LOVE NOTE CAUSE DON'T F*CKING FORGET US MILLENNIALS ARE ACTUALLY MENTALLY IMPAIRED they go into Spotify just to plug in certain songs into the f*cking movie. There's absolutely no reason it needed to be in the movie other than that btw guess what the hacker is actually the princess WHO WOULD HAVE GUESSED? ITS LITERALLY THE PLOT TO WRECK-IT-RALPH I actually empathized with the villain. Not because I was supposed to, cause you're not, but because the other characters are just so awful. The villain was almost kind of funny at moments, and in truth killing our main emoji dude would have been the only way to save the phone world. Overall she has more of a purpose and more defined goals than any other character in this film. also can we talk about the mid-credits scene. Cause yeah I was so disturbed by what I had seen that I couldn't move from my chair so I sat there until this scene rolled up wait first let me say that Anna Faris or whatever her name is might be the worst voice actress I've ever heard. And by might be, I mean it's not even close OK so the end credits scene directly contradicts the end of the movie. The movie ending has all the characters being accepted into the COOL EMOJIS CLUB I HONESTLY WISH I WAS MAKING THIS SH*T UP. But in the credits scene we see a bunch of the lame emojis and the evil smiley lady in the basement for loser emojis. Like the emoji movie even failed at its message that everyone should be liked/equal or some corny sh*t like that.FINAL MESSAGE: this movie makes the angry birds movie look like a masterpiece. If this movie came out during the cold war, the USSR would show it to its civilians as anti-American propaganda to show how stupid and consumer obsessed we are. If an alien race was to decide the fate of this planet based solely on watching this film, they would no doubt decide to exterminate humanity.

Ever since The Lego Movie was made, I've taken it upon myself to be open to more ideas that sound like cash grabs, but could also be more. The Lego Movie sounded like a giant commercial for the toy company. Instead, it was smart tribute to the creativity it inspires and was very funny. That has made me realize that out of everything, storytelling can allow anything to be engaging if people can emotionally connect with it enough. If people could find that connection with a bunch of toys and bricks, whose to say that the same thing could be found with emojis?Most people with smartphones have used an emoji at some point. I myself like the ones that either engage laughter or show off that I'm trying to convey something smooth. While I have no problem using it every once and a while, I dislike it when it becomes the prominent way of communication. I haven't asked any teenagers about that, but I'm sure that most of them still need text to order specific food or to tell their parents that their out until midnight. I like the think that all teens are smart, but The Emoji Movie makes them an unsalable group. In the smartphone of high schooler Alex (played by Jake T. Austin), is where all the emojis live where they live and work a part of the texting app. Meh emojis Mel (played by Steven Wright) and Mary (played by Jennifer Coolidge) are about their see their son Gene (played by T.J. Miller) go off to be used in his first text. Gene seems to have the ability to show other expressions and that happens when his text goes wrong. The leader of the emojis Smiler (played by Maya Rudolph) talks with other emojis like the Devil Emoji (played by Sean Hayes), dancer emoji (played by Sofia Vergara) and Poop emoji (played by Patrick Stewart) about what to do.When Gene gets word that he is likely to be deleted, he escapes with the hand emoji, HI-5 (played by James Cordon). Upon leaving the texting app, he finds a jailbreak emoji (played by Anna Faris) who tells him that if they can get to the Icloud, then his source code can be fixed. From there, they go through several apps including Candy Crush, Instagram, Just Dance, and more while everybody learns about being themselves...or something like that.Sony pictures should be ashamed. The Emoji Movie has to be one of the most obvious product plug movies ever made. I thought The Internship (the movie about Google) was bad, but this sets a new record. Not only do the story rip off Wreck it Ralph, Inside Out and The Lego Movie, but several times, the plot just stops to make another advertisement. If anything, I felt like I just sat through an introduction for a cult; a cult that clearly does not understand how teenagers, computers, programs, apps, games, and emotional storytelling work. Even for it's obnoxious tie ins, how are the characters? As hard as the majority of these actors try, this script does everything to suck out anything funny or interesting. This is more then a bad movie; this is a black mark on a resume that is likely to hurt every single person involved. I cannot remember anytime that I laughed, nor even heard a chuckle from the kids in my theater. I can only imagine that the parents that took their kids to this were punishing them. I wouldn't have been that cruel to my own. This is a movie that simply appeals to no one (it's too adult for kids and too stupid for the teenage audience they would have been the better targeted crowd).Is the animation even worth noting? Even that suffers from the story. Because the majority of the emojis are necessarily bright for their use, this doesn't allow them to pop out. It's just a mess of pixilation and phone advertisements. This kind of movie makes me mad that millions of dollars are spent making this garbage over original stories that aspiring artists are trying to pitch.I'll give this one poop emojis out of five. This movie doesn't even deserve a formal ending, so I'll end it on this: Shame on you Sony Shame on you Sony Shame on you Sony Shame on you Sony

Hated it. Here is why:
-As broken and cringe as humanly possible. I felt myself shiver during some scenes. I was just cheated out of 2 precious hours of my life.
-It was filled with product placements so blatantly pointless and awful I was hard pressed to not bury myself in a deep, deep hole in the ground with a ticking time bomb. A character even goes as far to say "We have to make it to Dropbox!"
-It was boring. I expected at least a little bit of decent action. None.
-It is a rip off of a lot of animated miracles of the decade. Like Inside Out or The Lego Movie. Or Wreck it Ralph. It explores characters trying to express themselves (Inside Out), Crazy haired feminists (The Lego Movie's Wildstyle, except the "feminist" in The Emoji Movie was kind of a vehicle to propel what is right nowadays), and going to different apps (Wreck it Ralph, apps instead of video games).
-The "jokes" were so unoriginal and predictable and unfunny I had to have a cold water bottle next to me so I could douse myself to stop my brain from overheating.
-The ending of this abomination should have made me happy. You know, the movie is over, I can go back to living a regular life, but it didn't. It was so infuriatingly out of touch about how kids act nowadays that I was considering tearing out my brain and selling it for export so I wouldn't have to remember it. In fact, this whole movie was out of touch with what will make an audience happy. It only exists to capitalize on the popularity of emojis. I could shun this movie even more, but won't. Just, ignore it. Okay guys?
Thanks.

'THE EMOJI MOVIE': Two and a Half Stars (Out of Five) A computer animated kids movie about a world of living emoji symbols, where a 'meh symbol' malfunctions and is hunted down to be deleted. The film stars the voices of T.J. Miller, James Corden, Anna Faris, Maya Rudolph, Steven Wright and Jennifer Coolidge. It was directed by Tony Leondis, and it was written by Leondis, Eric Siegel and Mike White. The movie has received almost unanimously negative reviews from critics and film fans alike (on IMDb at least), but it did do well at the Box Office still (kids seem to like it). I found it to be pretty pointless, and not really humorous at all, but it's not as bad as the reviews make it out to be either.The story is set in Textopolis; a digital city of emojis that all live inside the phone of a teenager named Alex (Jake T. Austin). Gene (Miller) is a meh symbol, who has the special ability to make many different expressions. On his first day of work, Gene panics and makes the wrong expression. This causes Alex to lose faith in his phone, and it puts all of Textopolis in danger. The leader of the text center, a smiley named Smiler (Rudolph), decides that Gene is a malfunction and she orders him to be deleted. Gene flees, with the help of a once popular emoji named Hi-5 (Corden), who's now lost his fame, and a hacker named Jailbreak (Faris). Smiler sends bots after them to delete Gene.The movie seems like a decent enough kids' flick; it's colorful, adventuresome and mildly amusing (the voice cast does decent enough work too). I of course wasn't entertained by it, but of course the movie wasn't made for me obviously. Kids seem to like it, so it's hard to claim that it's a horrible film. There's not much of anything in there for adults though, and it definitely doesn't have anything of substantial value to teach children. So I'd say it's an OK kids flick at best, that's definitely nothing special (that's for sure).
Worst movie of 2017, by far. Full of cringy jokes, horrible story line, why was this movie created?

(Warning: Contains Minor Spoilers) One does not watch a film like The Emoji Movie expecting anything but corporate pandering from a company as vile as Sony. However the film somehow managed to be worst than my expectations. Considering I have seen both The Nut Job and Minions in theaters, saying The Emoji Movie is the worst animated film I have ever seen, and one of the worst films I have ever seen, shows that the true quality of this film. What's the plot? Gene the emoji wants to become "meh," as he is a malfunction. After destroying the emoji center, Smiler, who is simply annoying, wants to kill Gene. Gene finds a useless comic relief named Hi-Five, who leads him Jailbreak, a hacker emoji that has extremely forced character traits. You can assume that along the way there will be poop jokes, jokes that are so bad you don't even know they're jokes, bad outdated references, a void of likable characters and emotion (ironic for a film centered around emojis), forced feminism, a romance between meh and female meh that is focused on for around 20 minutes,and scenes, like the one centered in Just Dance, that are so blatantly awful and go on for so long, you will want to bludgeon yourself multiple times. Whenever you think the film can't get worse it does, and by the third act, my friends and I laughed so hard, since the ending was so nonsensical, pandering, and followed every clichÃ© you've seen in other awful kids movies, like the ending dance sequence, except they are executed worse. One may say there are worse films than The Emoji Movie, and there probably are. And by that I mean there may be a few films worse than it. But the mentality behind this film, created from a greedy company that wants to create low-effort garbage to exploit a young audience while having the audacity to also make fun of that audience, as lazily as one could. This company pushes back reviews to allow films like this to do well, and says that the film isn't bad because it is made for a certain age group. This company has no purpose, other than to leech off of your money, and to continue releasing mass quantities of terrible films, like The Star, and potentially Peter Rabbit. The day Sony goes bankrupt will be happy day for all of humanity. Let's hope that day is sooner rather than later.

Since "Toy Story" became an enormous box- office hit and a beloved modern masterpiece by giving audiences an inspired look at what ordinary toys do when their owners aren't around, Hollywood has been striving to repeat that seemingly simple formula with a number of animated films that have offered viewers a privileged glimpse at the heretofore unseen existence of everything from the shelves of a grocery store (the execrable "Foodfight!") to the psyche of a young girl (the stunning "Inside Out"). Now comes "The Emoji Movie," a film that dares to ask "What goes on in the magical worlds contained within our cell phones?," a notion that I do not think that anyone has ever pondered for any amount of time outside of those stuck in a focus group at Sony Animation. That is only the first of many problems with this film, a work so completely devoid of wit, style, intelligence or basic entertainment value that it makes that movie based on the Angry Birds app seem like a pure artistic statement by comparison.The extremely dubious conceit of "The Emoji Movie" is that hidden within the messaging app in our phones is a teeming metropolis known as Textopolis, where all of the emojis live and wait to be called upon by their owners to say what mere words cannot. All emojis are supposed to have only one facial expression but Gene (T.J. Miller), who is supposed to be a "meh" like his parents (Steven WrightÂ andÂ Jennifer Coolidge), is just so darn exuberant that he is unable to stick with just one expression. This becomes a problem when his phone's owner, a 14-year-old boy named Alex struggling to reach out to the girl that he likes, selects Gene for a text he is sending to herâ€”Gene chokes at the last second and coughs up so many expressions that it is impossible to understand what he is supposed to represent. Discovering his secret and fearing what it could mean for everyone if one emoji seems to be malfunctioning, Smiler (Maya Rudolph), the always-grinning leader of Textopolis, decides to have Gene wiped out for good.Â Gene manages to escape Smiler's clutches and with the help of another outcast emoji, the once-popular Hi-5 (James Corden), he hits upon a plan to have himself reprogrammed to show only one expression so that he can finally fit in. The only emoji who can do this for him is master hacker Jailbreak (Anna Faris), who agrees to help him if he will come with her on a journey to the fabled Cloud, where his ability to change expressions could help her get past the impenetrable firewall protecting it. Their journey across the phone takes the three to a number of different apps and along the way, they learn valuable lessons about Being Yourself and Friendship and the like while being pursued by Smiler's troops, who have all been outfitted with illegal upgrades to make them extra-powerful. To make matters worse, Alex, having grown increasingly annoyed by the glitches inadvertently caused by Gene's journey, has made an appointment to have his phone and everything contained within completely erased.So what wonders lie just beneath our touch screens, anyway? Based on the evidence put forth by "The Emoji Movie," it is a combination of product placement and corporate synergy. Textopolis itself is an indifferently conceived and executed cityscape populated by any number of familiar emojis, the most famous of which is presumably Poop, who is voiced by none other than SirÂ Patrick StewartÂ in one of his less dignified gigs. Once we get outside the walls of Textopolis, we are essentially placed into a series of mini-ads for well- known apps that range from brief detours to the lands of Facebook and YouTube to extended commercials for the Candy Crush and Just Dance games. Since nothing of import goes on during these scenes (or any others, for that matter), I found myself speculating on which ones spent the most money to appear in the film based on the length of their exposure and the praise that they receive from the characters. Based on the available evidence, Dropbox must have been the big spender hereâ€”not only is it the all-important gateway to the Cloud but the characters manage to safely hide out from the bad guys there because, and I quote, "they are illegal malware and this app is secure." Then again, my guess is that the film could have gone into profit solely from taking money from companies eager to keep their apps as far away from this as possible.

I hate this movie. I mean, a movie about emojis? What the hell were these people thinking?!? First off, the plot. If you seen the endless spiral of cheesy "Be YOURSELF" kids movies, you seen the plot of this. Okay, it's this, an emoji has more than one emotion (gee, where have I've seen THIS before?), and the phone is getting deleted, IDK what else the plot is but product placement or ads. Second of all, the characters. They're the blandest characters I've seen all year. Gene is the generic "guy who is different than the rest who is accepted in the end", Hi-5 (who's idea of a name is this?), "the comedy relief who is annoying and as hyperactive as a 3 year on sugar", and Jailbreak, the "hardened chick who is kinda of a feminist that would fit in well with the Tumblr crowd of edgy 20 somethings" Also, there are other characters who are completely one dimensional and only used for "teh plot" and/or comedy. Finally, this movie sucked big time. The only positive thing is that most people hate it, including children. That restored some of my faith in humanity. Anyways, this is Princess Radar signing out.

The Emoji Movie is not the worst movie ever. Yes this movies has its limitations in a lot of places, and honestly, I can't think of another movie made blatantly based on the assumption, "KIDS WILL WATCH ANYTHING!" mentality but it's not the worst. I've heard people say, "It's just a kids movie! Were you really expecting a masterpiece out of an emoji?"First off, animated movies have broken our expectations before. If you can make a masterpiece out of; a rat who wants to be a chef (Ratatouille), a penguin who can surf (Surf's up), oh and A PANDA WHO WANTS TO DO MARTIAL ARTS (Kung Fu Panda), you can make a good movie out of just about anything, regardless of who made it. Also, the "It's just a kids movie" is just the laziest excuse ever. I personally think that children deserve good movies too, and not just a distraction to gawk and laugh at. The movies I mentioned above can actually be enjoyable for people other than 5 year old's. And no, lovely animation and a 'good message' isn't enough anymore.I will say a few positives, like the animation is amazing, a few jokes got a guilty smile out of me, and I admire Jailbreak's line: "How can you be number one, if there are no other numbers?" So, one or two things to enjoy, but just skip it, and show your kids a better movie.

I've been on record saying that I hate it when films, TV shows and content in general is released intending to appeal the younger demographic containing nothing to challenge them and just sticks to the safe route.What we're presented with here pretty much falls under that bracket as Sony farts out this abomination of a film which really just exists to sell advertising. How much of a base level have we sank to where we've gotten to the stage where Sony thinks we can be entertained by something so basic and pandering.The plot is essentially a rip off of Wreck it Ralph where TJ Miller emoji, Anna Faris emoji and James Corden emoji go off the rails trying to find sanctuary as opposed to their dull existence serving the phone user. The conundrum in the human world is just the phone user stressing out over what emoji to send his crush to win her affections. I'm just there thinking, "are you actually kidding me?" How out of touch are these mid-life crisis suffering writers, that they think that the youth of today will relate to something so insultingly simplistic?The product placement of the phone apps such as Twitter, Instagram, Candy Crush, etc. are incredibly on the nose too. It's pandering to the extent that you will almost be offended by it.Avoid this film at all costs. They cast Patrick Stewart as the poop emoji! How much of a deterrent do you need?!

Alex is a boy trying to connect with classmate Addie through his phone's messaging app Textopolis. Inside the phone, each app is a world upon itself. In Textopolis, Gene is an emoji eager to follow his parents' footsteps as another Meh. He fails in his first attempt and in the ensuing chaos, emoji leader Smiler sets bots to erase Gene. Hi-5 joins him in escaping into the world of the phone. Hi-5 leads them into a pirate app to find hacker Jailbreak to fix Gene.The start is good. I like the old emoticons walking into the retirement home. Despite the really stupid premise, I'm still willing to give this a chance hoping for some old Tron magic. The start is simply a fake out as the movie deteriorates into nothing. I couldn't stand it even with the very short 80 minutes worth of viewing. The poop jokes are fully expected but still insufferable. Why would Alex send the Meh emoji in the first place? It's all bright colors and meaningless stupidity. It may still be enjoyable for really young kids with their first phones. They may have fun with this idiocy.
I think its one nice family movie with good animation.

Saw this movie last night and I cannot fathom the negative reviews. Because, frankly, it's about as good as say any of these animated movies. It's on par with Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs, or Wreck it Ralph.Sure it's by the numbers, but newsflash - they ALL ARE.It looked great, it was funny - enough - and it had just enough charm. To clarify: it succeeded by ticking all the boxes with the bare minimum, but it's so similar to movies of its kind, I cannot understand why it's rated so low.Because if you liked Bee Movie, you're going to like this. OK so it's not quite as well rounded as Bee Movie (or in fact any of the successful animated movies), but it's certainly not far off.Ultimately it's a silly 90 minutes - and that's all it was ever supposed to be.I was pleasantly surprised.

I didn't believe that this movie was going to be as bad as other reviews said it was. I was wrong. After watching this movie I had to take a break from life. I returned home and laid down on the couch and just stared at the ceiling. I couldn't do anything and to be honest I didn't want to. I started questioning the reality of this world and the future of animation. It's safe to say that I became a hollow shell of my former self after seeing this movie. Jitterbug echos in my head every time I close my eyes now thanks to this corporate garbage.

"It's just a kids film, you don't have to be to harsh on it" An average excuse from people who don't understand the power of animation. A medium that let's your imagination fly with emotional and powerful movies, with great messages and great different styles, and what did Sony Pictures Animation offered to us? An 88-minute evil, stupid, manipulative and offensive commercial. Yes, it's a commercial, not a movie. Because the film is so focused to promote apps and emojis instead of thinking how to make this movie work.People might be overrating the Lego movies, but it's justified. As much as it's an excuse to sell Legos, it had an actual creative team that thought a good script first, and then how to sell it. Same case with Toy Story, they had a creative and inspired team that loved animation and cared about this concept as silly it sounds, and it worked.The emoji movie doesn't want to be creative, funny or at least unique in any aspect. It's your typical "be yourself" movie but with characters that are mean spirited with no personality, with a story that makes no sense and with really bad morals about treating the rest of people. This is a "movie" that embraces the smartphones and apps and tells you that you should depend on your phone instead of talk with real people and live the real life.This is a "movie" that manipulates you with pop songs, random and stupid jokes, bad animation and awful dialogue to buy everything they offer in this commercial and to make you think that the things they say in this movie is "profund".This is a "movie" that says that it's OK to be yourself, but you need to break rules and do nothing to fix your problem unless it's buying a smartphone.This is a "movie" that it's already dated by the time to review is posted, that shows no compassion to the kids, that treats the audience like stupid people who went to see this and insults every piece of minimum of cleverness just to the sake to sell toys about emojis.Sony Pictures Animation failed so bad to make this movie a franchise and it shows they don't know how to make a good animated movie, because they are more focused on how to market this towards children.It's a waste of time and no other kid should see this by its own merits ever again. It needs to be banished from the history of film making and from the art of animation.You want to show something for your kids? Let them watch anything else instead of Emoji movie. Because it doesn't teach anything good, it's mean spirited, it's too stupid to be taken seriously and it's too annoying and uninspired to be a comedy.Don't watch it ironically, don't watch it for the memes, don't watch it as a family film, just avoid everything that it's related with this horrible product. Trust me, you'll regret if you see it.I've warned you.

Ever wonder what would happen if somebody made a movie in which every clichÃ© ever was used with nothing original being added? No? Well what if I told you there was a movie that made Jaws 4: The Revenge look like Alien or made the Room look like The Godfather? That movie isn't even on par with the awful disgrace to humanity that is the Emoji movie. This is not even close to being a good movie. If you can even call it a movie, it's the worst movie ever made! And there have been lots of bad animated films, hell lots of films in general, what is this the year 2017. But I think this one takes the awful cake made out of rotten eggs made out of smartphone emoji's. It's a rip off of The Lego Movie, Inside Out, and Wreck it Ralph all at once, and it is beyond any doubt the worst thing that Sony ever created. Worse than Hotel Transylvania, worse than Open Season, worse than the Smurfs reboot, worse than the Annie remake, worse than Battlefield Los Angeles, worse than After Earth, worse than Pixels, worse than Ghostbusters 2016. There may be films that are worse in plot like Home on the Range, worse aesthetically like Shark Tale, or worse character wise like Norm of the North. But in terms of overall quality, this is the all time low! Stay away! Stay away as far as possible! THE ABSOLUTE ONLY THING THIS MOVIE CAN DO IS MAKE YOU APPRECIATE OTHER MEDIA! If you disregard my previous advice and watch this film anyway, and somehow manage to sit through it, don't expect a gold medal. You just wasted your time, and I feel bad for you. Likewise if you got this warning too late, once again you have my condolences, especially if you're on the younger side. BUT, you will be able to actively appreciate other media. You'll look at Jurassic World the way you see King Kong, you'll see Sword Art Online the way you see The Last Airbender (the TV series), and you'll see Brave the way you see Toy Story! Go watch any of those before you see this movie, but if you ignore my advice, whenever you watch another form of media at least you'll be able to say without a doubt, "I've seen a lot worse."

Everyone keeps saying this movie is terrible but it's not that bad.I think anyone will admit that it's not exactly polished; a lot of the jokes are too in-your-face, there's an over abundance of puns and a lot of the dialogue is heavy and awkward but that doesn't mean it isn't fun.The inspiration apparently came from toy story and continues a tradition of compiling real pop culture references that we saw in Roger Rabbit, Food Fight and Wreck It Ralph though the movies actual narrative seems most indebted to the Lego movie with its themes of conformism and creativity of expression.I like the message even if it is kind of ham fisted, both our protagonist Gene and the female lead Jailbreak are likeable even if JailBreak is blatantly just Wyldestyle from the Lego Movie and James Cordon's High comic relief as High Five is maybe kind of annoying but that's more due to lame jokes than any intrinsic problem. I found the antagonist actually pretty creepy, as are all perpetually happy people.Ultimately I came away feeling warmly about the movie for it's rich, distinctive world, positive message and how it embodies an aspect of its time while tying it to a universal them even if it's not exactly subtle about it.

While the idea for the film is clever, it doesn't seem to have been executed very well, there were some moments that had me smiling, but, the film will become outdated quickly, with, it's pop music & use of trends as jokes, not a potential classic, but, enough to keep kids entertained.

This film tells the story of an emoji that is unable to keep its facial expression to the assigned expression. He is ostracised by the emojis, and he has to find a way to hack the source code so he can have a constant facial expression."The Emoji Movie" is actually not as bad as I thought it would be. The plot basically says that it is alright for a social outcast to be himself. Along the way, the story utilises expressions, games and apps in daily life. It tries to be as close to real life as possible, so that people can easily relate to the film. However, there are times when it feels like several apps have paid big money to be prominently featured in the story. It is an entertaining story, albeit brainless and less refined.

In my "Top Gun" review, I said there was nothing wrong with the 'commercial' look of the film since the product placement is the whole setting. I sarcastically added: 'except for the emoji movie'. To be fair, I hadn't seen the movie. Now, I did. Do I withdraw my statement? Nope.But let's face it, criticizing "The Emoji Movie" would be like Homer Simpson repetitively hitting the Krusty burglar with that kid crying "stop it, stop it, he's already dead". No need to punch the cadaver or shoot the ambulance as French say, "The Emoji Movie" achieve one milestone by becoming the first film to win the Worst Picture Razzie... it did so brilliantly that commentators went pretty creative on it (one remembers the Rotten Tomatoes consensus). I'll try to be more constructive.Let's examine the film. First, it's not the 'product placement' that is problematic, besides "Top Gun", you have many quality films that couldn't do without brandname-dropping ("The Social Network", "Cast Away"...). The real insult is that the writers took our 'wow' for granted just because we're having familiar everyday technology on the big screen. Some bits like the Firewall or the Dropbox were okay but did we need that lengthy dancing app sequence? Couldn't have they come up with something more imaginative with at least ONE social network?Some would argue that the real mistake was to make a bland cardboard character out of the young smartphone owner... and that predictable crush no one could care about. I think it's downright impossible to make a deep soul connection between emojis and people Ã  la "Inside Out" (which it obviously ripped off). It's tough enough to make emojis as relatable as humans but humans are bound to appear as predictable and boring as emojis if they're defined by them. Now, would have the film worked better if it was just about Emojis? You know, like the Smurfs... but how do you make an Emoji movie without their main users?Gosh, must have been one hell of a brainstorming session in that conference room!Now, supposing humans are relegated to supporting players (after all, it did work for the Lego movie) but then how about the Emoji characters? You have a 'Meh' emoji who refuses to be defined by one expression: we got it: MISFIT. You have Jailbreak as the female who doesn't want to be 'categorized' and rejects love, we got it: GIRL POWER. Hi-5 is the comical sidekick, and Patrick Stewart is the prestigious cameo, voicing Poo. And you know what? That's not even the problem.Have a respectable actor voice a poo, and it's an average gag at best. Have him say only poo-related jokes, it kills, annihilates and exterminates the fun. Humor is a matter of contrast, so let's just have a poo behaving like a respectable citizen (did I just write that?) Having the Big Bad as a Smiley was an interesting twist... although nothing new (cough *Joker*). Now, don't get me start on 'Meh' parents, the most tired joke of the film, and the responsible for a puzzlement I never thought I'd have: do emojis reproduce? Do 'Meh's go only with 'Meh's? Are emojis racist? Do a crying and a happy one made a happy tears one?Like another film I reviewed recently, "The Emoji Movie" is a film that the more it makes sense, the less it does. The premise is ludicrous though it had potential, the treatment was predictable but exploiting many overused tropes from better movies, the product placements were superficial, the human world didn't make us care and ultimately, it's hard to imagine Emojis as living creatures.Finally, I remembered the way I use my own emojis: my favorite are the Thumbs Up when I want to save myself writing two lines of approval, the kissing heart when I receive pictures of babies... which makes me realize that I hate when I get only emojis as answers. Let's be honest, emojis are semantic loopholes, products of our intellectual laziness and yet the film portrays them as a pillar of the new-age communication. I wouldn't say no one wants to watch a movie to remember how lobotomized we are by these little creatures... but not one that gives a noble dimension to their existence.Now, there's a hidden relevance in the film, something that could have elevated it to the level of social comment, had it dared to have an edge, to end with a moral twist where the boy would win the girl's heart by just talking to her... how about having that message communicated to the climax 'talk to her' or something like that... that the film obviously makes the emojis the alpha and omega of the life of a teenager could only foreshadow its failure. Not to say that there aren't good moments, the animation can please the kiddies on a mindless level, although the graphics might be too overstimulating.Still, I'm glad the film was made because if cinema needs masterpieces, it also needs a few occasional big stinks. Movies like "Cats" or "Batman and Robin". Movies that reveal how far Hollywood marketing can go in its faith on our mediocrity and how low it can sink for the sake of cash-making flashy idiocy.Cinema needs movies that make audience say "enough is enough', movies that show that even the lousiest gimmicks are supposed to serve a plot, that kids aren't just dim-witted consumers who'd grab anything just because it's got pretty nice colors.There's a limit to how far you can push the me-toos (I mean the marketing strategy) to emulate dinosaurs, while reality put you back to the state of La Fontaine's frog that wished to be as big as an Ox and so she started puffing herself out and kept doing it more and more. What happened to her is the perfect metaphor for "The Emoji Movie" ultimate fate.

Being a person who's outer expression is mostly 'meh', I will now be reminded of this movie whenever I'm aware of my outward indifference.
So now I feel like I've been forever tainted.Most people have slammed this as the worst thing to ever be made. That's harsh, even though I don't completely disagree. But I have seen worse things.
Still, why 2 stars and not 1 or less?
Well, 1 is for the voicing talent of T.J. Miller. I like the guy. He's what made the Silicon Valley series funny. And here, just hearing his voice, felt comforting. He's like that friend with the cool voice and the interesting stories (true or not) who can talk forever non-stop, but you don't mind because they fill up a void with life. They entertain when you can't be bothered to make an effort. The life of the party when you're happy to take a backseat and just chill whilst nursing your drink. He makes a good buddy.The other 1 star just has to go to the sheer audacity of making a movie about emojis in the first place.
What would Disney and Pixar writers from 20 years ago make of this? Even the writers of the dystopian Wall-E (2008) would have not predicted the dystopian direction of something like The Emoji Movie becoming a reality.
Still, the pitch to Sony (or Columbia Pictures) would have been easy enough.
'Emojis come in a variety of expressions,' they would say. 'So many of them. And each of them can be a different character. Then there's all the animals. And body parts. And objects. And... all the other things you can send in a text that isn't a letter. All of those are characters, so the world building is easy peasy.
At this point, Sony (or Columbia Pictures) are almost on board. 'But what about the story?' they'd say.
Well, for the producers, that would be the easiest part. Just take a bit of Inside Out (the behind-the-scenes universe) and a bit of Wreck-it-Ralph adventure, and there you have it. The same old rehashed story told from another perspective. They'd argue that kids and young teens would gobble it up. Seeing their favorite emojis up on the screen would be a thing they never knew they loved, up until that moment.
'Just think of all the stuffed and plastic emoji toys that could follow after the movie's success,' they'd say.It was a gutsy move. Especially that it was a move made by grown-up responsible adults. Serious people talked about this in conference meetings and studio discussions and writer/animator sessions.Maybe the whole thing was a dare between the producers and creators? See if they could get something like this green-lit? Because that type of boldness deserves some form of respect, surely.
(Nevertheless, Netflix would have happily payed for it anyway if Sony had said no. But Netflix is hardly a challenge in getting something through, so they wouldn't count).

The storyline is generic and shallow - clichÃ©d and uninspired, it feels less like a movie and more like a long commercial for smartphones and emojis. The overt product placement is distracting, making the whole thing feel like an extended advertisement rather than a genuine story with heart or originality.The humor falls flat with forced jokes and cringeworthy pop culture references that don't land. I agree with most critics and audiences: the comedy is unfunny and feels like it's trying too hard.What really disappoints is that this movie doesn't even come close to the quality of popular animated films. Sony canceled a promising Popeye project, and instead, we got this forgettable, meme-worthy disaster. I can only imagine the Popeye movie would've been a far better choice and likely received better reviews than the highly unpopular Robin Williams Popeye movie.The Emoji Movie feels like a cheap ripoff of Wreck-It Ralph, The Lego Movie, and Inside Out. I love those movies, but this one only manages to tarnish their legacy by comparison. Emojis are fun online, but turning them into characters going on a "phone adventure" is not creative or engaging.Honestly, it's not worth your time.Please don't let them make a sequel-The Emoji Movie 2 would only continue this unwatchable mess.

I know I'm a little late to writing a review for this movie but I just had to, after hearing how bad It Is and trailers didn't help one bit, I just had to see It and I didn't plan to, even the Nut Job 2 looked more funny then this... but that's not saying much.A little story before hand that's more funnier then the movie It's self, before It started me and my friend went to get our tickets by using a Unlimited card (Instead of paying my own money Instead thank god..), we go Into a screening, I sit down, put my snack and drink down and It was empty, just how I wanted It.But then the trailers started and were rated 15, which was strange because the film was rated PG (even though It was shown U on the BFFC Ident for some reason..) so I go outside and wait for my friend to come back, she does come back and I told her we might be at the wrong screening, so I look at the ticket and I was right we were at the wrong one, so we go Into the right one, I took a deep breathe before I went In and as I went In there was other people, not slit only like a group, like maybe three adults and three kids, so as film went on they were laughing with the movie, the puns the y'know "Unfunny" stuff.So I sat down and watched the film and..... yeah, It's terrible, like HOLY F**KING S**T! It's terrible and I'm not just saying that or agreeing It's true, where do I begin?, oh let's start with the concept which as expected copies Disney's Wreck-It Ralph, Pixar's Inside Out and a bit of LEGO Movie In there, three really great films that are WAY better then this... this! GARBAGE!.Another Issue Is the plot, characters and humour, why all In one?, because they are all same like In most kids movies, bland and very mean-spirited characters, generic plot and hit or miss humour and this movie does exactly that, I'll admit I did get a couple of chuckles out of this movie, coming from HI-5 and that's about It, that's properly the closest to be funny, everything else Is just cringey, unfunny and insulting, even the moral of being yourself really makes It more obviously cringey that It completely ripoff Inside Out!.The only plots that there Is are Gene's parents going out of Textroplis to look for him and main villain Smiler going on about deleting Gene and they are really pointless and predicable that they might as well remove It entirely, the characters also got through a lot of apps like YouTube, Facebook even the Twitter bird Is a character, they even show ApplePen on YouTube... and Gene says hashtag.. I'm not kidding, these people must be so obsessed with putting lots of advertising In their own movie about Emojis!... good grief..I guess the only tolerable that I like Is the animation, It's colorful, looks nice and well designed, well on the humans, the Emojis just look basic and dull, maybe If all of the problems I mentioned were fixed In a YouTube series about Emojis, I would of been fine with that, but to be released AS A MOVIE?! IN CINEMAS?! THIS IS LITTERLY CANCER!.So yeah the Emoji Movie SUCKS!, It's dull, unfunny, clichÃ©d, characters are a-holes, the idea and moral rips off other successful movies and the concept makes no sense, the animation Is okay and Hi-5 did me chuckle a couple of times, even the voice acting from talented people like TJ Miller, James Corden, Anna Farris and even Patrick Stewart feel wasted on this... piece of s**t!, jus... just don't see guys, they are better kids films out there to watch like Cars 3, Despicble Me 3 and Captain Underpants which I think are stilling In cinemas at this point.I wish to forget this movie entirely, It's worse then Norm of the North! and Ice Age: Collision Course!, yes I just said that Norm of the North was averagely bad and Ice Age 5'has some good things In It.As expected I'm giving this cancerous movie 0/10, do I need to explain why?

The second the movie was over, I was dumbstruck, and I wasn't the only one. When the movie ended I thought there would be a big round of applause but when I turned around I saw that about half the audience was still in their seats. I looked at a couple of people, some were speechless and most were crying. Nonetheless I didn't hear a word. When I thought about it, i realized an applause would have been ridiculous. When someone asked me how the movie was I was going to say it was amazing, but that wouldn't have done the movie justice. The movie was an extremely moving, emotional experience. As a non-Christian who nevertheless respects the historical figure of Jesus Christ and the beauty of his philosophy and teachings, I found The Emoji Movie to be a powerful portrayal of much that I think is worthwhile about the Christ story. I know the film has been maligned for anti-semitic content (perhaps because Gene make mistakes in the film and are seen as the villain instead of the hero), and for various other problems - but let's face it - any movie portraying this subject was bound to face strong reactions. And kudos to Tony Leondis for not shying away from the subject by creating a sterile, gutless, Disney story out of what really was a good example of the everyday horror of life on the fringes of the millennial empire. Leondis invents a new genre with The Emoji Movie - that of historical horror. The performances in this film are inspired. I felt that the film brought out the cowardice of the apostles very forcefully, and the courage of Gene life was palpable to the very end. I also felt that the voice acting from James Corden was one of a kind and compelling - almost making me believe that he was truly a Hi-5 in real life! Final word - this is not a film for the whole family nor is it a feel-good film. Don't see it if you're not willing to confront the worst aspects of human nature up close. And don't go in looking for your own version of the story - it's not your film! This is what Tony Leondis believes, and it's his own revelation, not necessarily to be shared by all.

The Emoji MovieGrowing up the only emoticon you were allowed to feel was: Smiling Face.As per this animated-adventure: Now there's a myriad of symbols to emote your psychosis.Inside of a teenager's phone lives a multifaceted face emoji, Gene (T.J. Miller), that doesn't want to be defined by his 'meh' designation, like his parents, so he teams up with a HI-5 sign (James Corden) and a hacker (Anna Faris) that can help fix his glitch before Gene is deleted.But to repair Gene they must survive Candy Crush, Instagram and Spotify.A platform for app and software companies to reach impressionable young minds, this commercial masked as a 3-D kids cartoon is corporate brainwashing. Intent on creating brand loyalty amongst preschoolers by way of cutesy characters, showing this schlock to minors should be deemed child abuse. Furthermore, who needs emoticons when every human emotion can be articulated by a dick pic? Red Light vidiotreviews.blogspot.ca

I really wish I could give this movie a zero. There are literally no redeemable qualities. You cant even argue that the animation was good, because by this point, its impossible to make it "ugly" unless you screw up by godly proportions. The sad thing is, this movie wasn't a failure. It made crap loads of money, even though everyone hated it.Please stop ironically giving this product good reviews. And someone hand me a bottle of cyanide.

Never has a movie made me as unreasonably angry as this movie has. Even before I watched, I could feel a pit of loathing form in the depths of my psyche. Probably because the movie's assertion that "emojis are the most important form of communication" offends me on a spiritual level. Or perhaps the very existence of this film reminds me just how banal, insipid, and base Hollywood's process of filmmaking has become. Rather than attempt to break new ground by trying something new with a new IP, Corporate executives, in their never-ending obsession to never take any risk, have birthed this cosmic terror upon the universe. This movie is the Foodfight of a new generation. There is no artistic merit to this movie, no philosophical message to convey besides the usual schlock one inserts into a children's movie such BE YOURSELF, YOU'RE SPECIAL, and all that drivel which might hit home in any other movie. This movie only exists to be a 1-hour and 31-minute advertisement. This film wastes substantial time with parts that suffer cancerous inclusion of real world apps, such as Spotify, Instagram, Just Dance, and Dropbox. If you might be thinking that The Emoji Movie is something that your children might want to see, shove those thoughts away now, because waterboarding is a more substantial past-time to inflict upon them. Your kids deserve so much better than this, an over glorified ad that is a microcosm of everything wrong with modern Hollywood.

How has the movie world succumb to this style of movie. I thought we had a lowering of the bar with Angry Birds, but noooooo.This generation of children are being poisoned by this anal bleaching of a movie.Avoid it - save yourselves its too late for me.

Okay, obviously people feel the need to be utterly sarcastic and ridiculous about tearing this movie down, but I didn't think it was that bad. I've been searching around for the movie greats on this website, and searched for some of the classics, like the Godfather, the Shawshank Redemption, Shindler's List, and Freddy Got Fingered, and I came across this beautiful, visually stunning masterpiece, assuming it will at least get an 8.3/10, and I was appalled to see such a low score on such a masterpiece. These primitive neanderthals think they have a sense of art? The morals and themes fly straight through there heads, while they are scratching their a**es for an hour and thirty minutes. Marlon Brando would be rolling in his grave, to see such an artistic beauty, rated a 2.8/10! I thought of Al Pacino, who did many classics, like Jack and Jill, when I saw TJ Miller's performance of Gene. Screw It! I thought of Gene Wilder! Just while I thought I was restoring my faith in humanity.Cheers, Bob Marley Writer, Actor, Director, Producer

This movie was basically a propaganda piece. The whole plot, characters and story line was just dire and completely unsuitable for young children watching. None of my children enjoyed the film which is not surprising. At the end you were left with a weird unsatisfied feeling that the film had achieved nothing and that was because the characters had achieved nothing.Again we see the result of basically feminist bs being fed into a film, and because they have been rejected and have ultimately failed in their love life they appear to want characters in films they have influence over to do the same thing.
