As others here have said, this film is really not a film at all but a movie length advertisement for smart phone apps that corporate America wants you and your children to download after you watch the "movie." It's just a shameless, cynical cash grab. Very sickening to say the least. Not only that, this film steals concepts from much better films such as Inside Out, Wreck-It-Ralph, and The Lego Movie. It's that unoriginal and lazy. I really feel particular disappointment in Patrick Stewart, whom I have enjoyed watching in the Star Trek franchise and the X-Men movies, but I guess even he is willing to sell his soul to play talking poop if the pay check is right. A shame.

After hearing what people said about this movie, I didn't have high hopes. Im sad that I am just now watching this beautifully animated movie. I went into it thinking it would be the worst movie I've ever seen, but after watching it, I feel bad for saying that. It's funny, lighthearted, and it takes you on a nice adventure. It really inspired me to take a hammer to my head. I highly recommend watching this if you haven't already:)

Where do we begin.Let's start with the whole concept of this movie. This is a prime example of the older generation trying too hard to appeal to us 'millennials' by including emojis. Instead, I feel more insulted more than anything, as the movie depicts us as zombies glued to our phones, as shown in the intro scene. They also canceled a Popeye movie for this garbage, which is truly disgraceful. Moving on to the content of this movie, let me start with saying it includes a plethora of unfunny poop jokes and puns that you can see coming a light-year away. If the writers believe their targeted audience would find their jokes humorous, then the writers are incompetent, immature five-year-olds. The plot is as barren as the surface of Pluto. There are no relevant plot twists and you can predict the exactly how everything is going to end, so I'm not sure if anyone can have the movie spoiled for them. The character are all empty clichÃ©s. A hero with no personality. Check. A comic relief. Check. A love interest for the hero. Check. A generic villain. Check. Every other character in an irrelevant one-liner. What were the themes of this movie? That's a tough one. All I could think of is... express your emotions? Which frankly is bullsh*t.tl;dr: Only watch this movie ironically. If you want decent things to watch, avoid this movie like a pile of feces contaminated with Ebola.

When I saw how much hate 'The Emoji Movie' was getting, I decided I had to see it for myself to see if it was justified. An animated kid's film with a sizeable budget couldn't possibly be that bad, right? Wrong. It is every bit as bad as the reviews suggest.This is by far and away the worst animated movie I have ever seen. It has literally nothing going for it, with everything from the plot to the script and characters being nothing short of dreadful. As if the idea itself isn't bad enough, they then have the audacity to stuff it full of product placement. It angers me to think that people actually went to the cinema to see what is effectively a 90 minute long advert.'The Emoji Movie' is just another example of a pitiful Hollywood cash grab, jumping on a social trend to make a quick buck. It is insulting even to the young children it is supposed to please. The worst film of the year by far!

Isn't it great that today's generation might as well go much low than this with social media? Given that I didn't see it, what do I think of it? ðŸ’©? No, I believe that's already been done to death. "This movie sucks?" No that's not it either. From now on, I'm just gonna call it the epitome of losing faith in humanity until I find a description that verbally and physically fit the movie's crude, idiotic, and juvenile ideas of humor! I doubt that NOBODY laughs when I get to see it. What reality does this movie deserve to exist?! I really want to know, I'm genuinely curious at this point. In this reality, it's conventional wisdom that it takes a sane person to prevent this movie from being made. What am I saying, it's already been made! I've seen bad movies and it never bothers me at the slightest. I'd seen Pixels! Hell, I'd even seen the Ghostbusters reboot! I'd even seen Transformers and not the sequels! Now, I've officially learned by the doing the right thing of seeing Atomic Blonde instead of the Emoji Movie. I think I believe calling it a kids movie is not going to work anymore, because children deserve better instead of being bored. This movie is indescribable. The Emoji Movie is not just 'bad,' but it is disturbing, brutal, terrible beyond words. The disgusting and depressing movie makes me want to go outside and hang myself. The sadness and coldness it brings to my heart is disgusting. I'm terrified of Sony. What will they do next? Publicly execute someone? No... no.... that's better than the Emoji Movie. There is so much more to this 'Emoji Movie' that makes me want to die... I literally left the room I was watching it in and nobody at all was surprised. I, myself am surprised none of the other people came with me. One of them was sitting on their phone the whole time, anyways, considering the boring aspect and truly disturbing, edgy characters. It's extremely clichÃ© and soul-crushing, you could just call it death. For the time I was in the room, I felt like I was being dipped in nuclear waste while on painkillers. You feel agony, then nothing, and then the agony of having your skin peeled off, and then you're dead. Nothing of who you were remains. This movie is like a badly made sandwich. It has the formula/order for one but the components are made of horse sh*t. The dialog was worse than a babbling toddler. The story is not boring, for it is revoltingly insulting to the budget this movie has somehow been trusted with. Seriously, the worst part has to be the budget.

I can't believe how much this movie is getting slammed. The awfulness of this film is like a plague. I was released just this past weekend and already its getting massive backlash. So, I had to see what the fuss was about. And I've got to say, its pretty embarrassing that we live in a world where something like this exists. I am a huge fan of animated films and I think they can appeal to any demographic. But this movie gives the business a bad rep. Hopefully other studios will see this disaster and try their best to avoid films like this. Sony Pictures is in a landslide with this one and its going to take something drastic to recover from this. I just don't see them making many more films after this. Who knows? Maybe the film's 50 million dollar budget will save it. But money aside, this is without a doubt an abomination. I'm not even going to get into the issues because it will take all day to write it. If you want to take a chance to see for yourself, go ahead. But don't say I or the tons of other critics didn't warn you. This is a film for the ages, and not in a good way. Oh yeah, Patrick Stewart voices a piece of poop. Can't believe I have to say that. Stewart deserves better. Here are the grades. Characters: F, Animation: A, Story: F, Screenplay: F, Overall: F

Terrible! Just terrible. I'm sorry, but this movie deserves to be shut down. Also, all of the reviews that claim the movie is 10 stars, are BOTS. I repeat, BOTS! They all use the word 'Masterpiece', similar grammar, personality, and a couple of them were somehow the same account name and profile picture. Do NOT waste your money on this movie!

I am lost for words. I didn't pay to see this so-called "movie" but I still want a refund of some sort. When I watched this "movie" I obviously wasn't expecting anything good but I just wanted to laugh at how sh*t it is but, my God, what I felt watching this was 1 hour and 25 minutes of Satan throwing his sh*t at me. I might as well just have received a kick in the nuts, at least the pain from that would fade! I remember my dad telling me about the times he went to see The Exorcist and A Clockwork Orange in the early 1970's and when he left the cinema, he and the rest of the audience were greeted by members of the Salvation Army at the cinema entrance giving everyone at the screening leaflets containing phone numbers to psychiatrists you should ring if you were psychologically effected by the film's content. I can definitely say I'll be needing therapy over the next few weeks to get rid of the horrible images of cringy "poop" jokes, awkward unfunny lines and the endless product placements of iPhone apps erased from my mind.No doubt there will be people trying to defend this *cough* "movie" by saying "It's a kids movie, what do you expect!" No. There are plenty of kids movies from both past and recent times like The Lion King,Toy Story, Inside Out and Wreck It Ralph (which btw are movies this film rips off) which the makers actually put thought, effort and care into their project and not some cheap lifeless unfunny 85 minuet advert for social media, Facebook, candy crush and other phone apps. AVOID!

This review will be short because I can sum it up in just a few words.This is the first time (out of thousands of movies) That I have ever gave a 1 out of 10.Longer version : There simply wasn't a single redeemable part of this movie. The animation was terrible (seriously it looks like something from 2004 not 2017), the story line um....there really isn't one except "Three unlikely friends have to save the world, but really don't do much to reach the goal until the final Macguffin. For an all star cast, it sounded like the actors all had guns to their head. Stale deliveries abound like the 800 product placements that litter this movie. In other words, I can almost always find something good in a movie. I never give out 1's. I VERY Rarely give a 10. To me, an 8 means it's a great movie. A 10 means it's just a work of art and transcends being just a movie. I think the worst score I've ever given before was a 3 because even in bad movies, there are redeeming qualities such as maybe great cinematography or a particular scene or actor that stuck out, or even just good editing.This movie has no redeeming qualities whatsoever. I took my niece and nephew to it (7 and 9 years old) and even they were asking "Can we just leave and go watch a different movie?" about 20 minutes in. And that's exactly what we did.Seriously, I hate that most people vote either 1 or 10 most of the time because why have a scale at all if you are one of those people. In this case, this movie deserves all of the 1's it gets.The only reason it is even rated 1.6 is because of the blatantly obvious corporate review shrills. So after being on IMDb for like 13 years now, I finally found a movie that was so bad that it earned my first 1 star rating. I'd give it a 0 if I could.

This movie is literally everything that is WRONG with the movie industry. It perfectly shows the absolutely laughable and desperate state that Hollywood is in right now. The dialogue of this "product" is so poor it honestly feels like they wrote it in an afternoon with little to no thought or creativity put into it.I am appalled by the unoriginality of this piece of animated garbage. If you're going to watch an animated kids movie with a similar plot that actually has some effort and care and attention put into it, then please just watch Inside Out, Wreck-It-Ralph or the Lego Movie. THOSE are good films that are memorable and fun to watch - this isn't.I beg of you, DO NOT go watch this pile of tripe ironically just to see if it's any good or not, because it is not. I absolutely promise you.

Why does The Emoji Movie exist? Why was this movie made? I can't believe some people thought making a movie about face icons on your phones would be a good idea. Well, it wasn't, and The Emoji Movie has to be the worst movie I've seen in quite some time. Some kids may find some enjoyment in this movie, but it's all from stupid jokes and seeing their favorite app in an animated movie. I think the biggest issue with this movie is the lesson it is expressing to kids. This movie's lesson is go on your phones and use emojis. That's the legit lesson, I am not kidding. Kids aren't learning anything good when watching this film, so they shouldn't watch it ever. I watched it with friends as a joke, and it actually was fun because we made fun of everything going on in the movie. The plot of this movie is very simple yet dumb, I feel like a seven year old could've made the script of this movie. Just the whole concept of emojis on phones going on an adventure sounds dumb. The Emoji Movie made $217 million at the box office!!! Like, why, what a waste of money. The budget was $50 million, and that money could've been used for a new film maker to make their first theatrical release, or could've been donated to charity. I think that $50 million was a big oof by sony animation. Making the movie was also a waste of time. That time making the movie could've been used to volunteer at a local soup kitchen, or making a better movie. I'd obviously give The Emoji Movie a 1/10.

At first I didn't think I would like this movie because of all the bad reviews it was getting but I actually enjoyed it. I don't remember hardly anything from this but I remember it was bad. Unfunny.

"How bad could this movie be" was my feeling before watching this. And to be honest, pretty bad. Main idea of the movie seems to be hand jokes, name dropping different apps and references to basically any entertainment related things. Towards the end I was just trying to find all these references. It's like the movie tried to take the plot from wreck-it Ralph and Inside out, but fails miserably. Mix in some forced gender equality and you end up with a pretty bad movie. Best parts were cat video, poop emoji and few actually funny hand jokes. But too much is too much. I did watch the whole movie, so it wasn't all bad. Maybe if it wasn't just about the puns, the movie could've had it's moments. Now there really weren't.
The disgusting thing is that all the smart-asses with the sarcastic 10's probably made the production deceide to do another emoji movie. Good job you dips.

I think the ratings on this movie are harsh! It is a kids film to be primarily enjoyed by kids not adults, and from what I gathered at the busy cinema - it was! My 6 year old certainly enjoyed it! And to be honest I didn't think it was that bad either (and I've sat through some unbearable kids movies!).

This movie is just garbage. My sister & I wanted to watch a movie and this was on our recommended. I knew this movie was bad before watching it, but decided to give it shot since I was bored and had nothing to watch. The idea of the movie was creative and original, but the execution was terrible & full of cliches. Some scenes were so bad & cringy I had to look away, like the part with the Just Dance app, and the "Emoji Pop" dance. The only reason I gave it 2/10 is because the idea was cool.
This movie is proof that we are doomed as a species.

I find emojis useful to some extent; however, I tend to type things out. I do use a smiley face from time to time and a few others, but emojis started getting out of hand as people literally think crap is cute thanks to stupid emojis. So guess what, they made a movie out of them! Yes, why not, you have a built in product tie in as there are already emoji pillows and such out there. So Sony, makes another huge mistake to go along with making Ghostbusters again and promoting it by attacking its audience, by screwing up Spider-man twice by making two sets of films with no proper endings to either (thankfully, they finally let Marvel help) by making an emoji movie and they make it as bad as one would think a film about pointless symbols can be! Seriously, the story is horrid.The story has emojis living within our phones and they live in an emoji town. They go to their job which is a box where they get scanned and then appear on the phone. What? That is the most absurd crap ever. Why not just emojis living in a city do their thing, why make them be in a phone because we already no they are just data and not creatures living in our phone. Well, one emoji, the 'meh' emoji cannot do 'meh', he can apparently do everything which gets him in trouble with smiley face and soon he is being hunted because the kid whose phone they are on is going to delete his phone. So 'meh' must try to become 'meh' with the help of high five and a hacker. And the studio put money behind this. There are a couple of funny parts to this one, but seriously, it just is not a good film. Studios these days pass by good stories every day for something like this and who can blame them? People pass up films unless it is tied to something these days or a sequel. Seriously, they are making Star Wars films every year now and people get excited to see them. Why not make a film about something that can easily be turned into a toy? Thankfully, this film was not a huge super success, still wondering how the hell this cost 50 million to make. Unfortunately, it did make the studio a profit so I can see a direct to DVD or Netflix sequel coming out. I am sure if there is one it will be even more 'meh'.

Let me tell anyone who reads this why this movie is the worst:(even though I haven't seen it but I've heard about it.)The Name of This Movie: Unoriginal, uninspired, and can already tell the viewer(s) that it is a futile attempt at pandering to this generation Animation: The only about this movie than isn't bland and/or awful is the animation. Just because it looks okay doesn't make it any better. Plot: The plot of this movie has been done to death and is similar to beating a dead horse. (The plot is that everyone is normal except for one guy who is different and that makes him "weird", so he possibly goes on a journey to become normal and at the end, he realizes that being different is what makes him special.) There are so many other movies that do this plot and handle it much better than this "movie" does. (for example, Wreck It Ralph)Product Placements: There are so many product placements (for example, Candy Crush, Facebook, Twitter, Just Dance, Dropbox, Spotify, etc.) that it's intrusive and a cheap series of attempts at capitalizing on the audience that uses these apps. In other words, the ludicrous amount of product placements makes this film The Advertisement Movie. (as I like to call it.)The Characters: The characters (as far as I know) are bland and don't really get any character development at all. The hacker emoji character is a rip-off of the character Wyldstyle from The Lego Movie, which is much better than this waste of money.Conclusion: Do not watch this film, you would be better off spending your money on any other movie that is not this one. Do not watch this movie, all it will do at most is that it might keep the children awake but even the children will probably get bored and ask to leave the theater and go back home. In other words, anyone who reads this review (and even those who don't read it) would be better off watching paint dry for about 90 minutes and giving their $10 (or so) to charity.Final Review Score: 0 out of 10 (if it was possible to give it a 0 on this site.)

*** This movie has gender politics *** Despite the shocking ratings for this movie, it's actually better than the other children's release at the moment (which also suffers from gender politics), the Ninjago Movie. Who is pushing sexism on young children? Why is it always one sided sexism? The Ninjago movie lacked heart. The Emoji movie has heart (especially due to T. J. Miller's performance). You end up liking most of the characters. However, the story is very predictable and leaves little to the imagination. This is what separates this movie from a Pixar movie. Pixar movies have heart and brains.If you really have to pick a movie for the holiday season for your children, get out an old movie so you don't have to deal with the gender politics ("why are men always taking credit for what women do" type of garbage). If you're desperate for a cinema experience, pick the Emoji movie.

When the trailer came out, I too fell victim to the hate train hype this movie was building. Is the movie good? No. Is it the worst thing ever? Probably not. I understand the hate this is getting, seeing how absurd the subject matter is. In execution it is less bad than it is just generic and forgettable. Many people thought this would be a so bad it's good flick. It's not bad enough to pull that off. It's also not bad enough to be insulting and painful to watch. It really is just a generic kid's film. In my experience, the movie went by pretty quickly, and I never really felt too bored or offended. Once the hate hype dies down, no one will remember this film.

This review for The Emoji Movie is spoiler free* (1/5) "THE MOST IMPORTANT form of communication are emojis," narrates T.J. Miller's Gene towards the start of The Emoji Movie is just one of the messages that can be found throughout Sony Pictures' cash cow scheme to bring in more money from a bad movie, which of course with the title Emoji Movie what's more to expect? Yes, this is the worst animated feature of the year for mainly one reason is that animations can be seen as the most creative form of film, however the idea to have multiple facial expression as the protagonists is possibly the laziest from of creativity. The Emoji Movie opens with Gene a multi-expressional Emoji who can change his expression by the flick of his face; his quest is to be placed on the screen for his user. He lives with other Emojis in Textville a world filled with different faces and emotions. The plot is essentially that Gene is fired from Textville's message board called The Cube, so he sets out on a quest to become a normal Emoji. That's pretty much it. Is there more to having a multi-expressional Emoji who tries to become normal? Of course, because for that it would have to follow logic and, from the off there is no logic here. There are many references to other, better forms of communication which of course our characters travel through in order to get to Cloud through Dropbox it's a continuous spiral of references and piling bad puns which can be seen from a mile away and will have you shacking your head. At its best the animation colourful (though mostly yellow) and brings all these emojis to full colour â€“ even this deviates between cheap rubbery animation techniques to knock-off Pixar. There is even a short before the film based on Sony's own Hotel Transylvania in a vague attempt to follow Pixar success. In terms of cast, choosing T.J. Miller as Gene isn't a bad choice as he delivers some perhaps extended charm to the feature. With him there is a wide variety of different voices to hear firstly there's, Smiler (Maya Rudolph), Jailbreak (Anna Faris) a hacker, Hi-5 (James Corden), Mel Meh (Steven Wright),and finally there's Poop (Patrick Stewart) â€“ though these are clever casting choices they are given nothing funny to say, in fact most of the things they do say is piled on by bad puns â€“ "I'm always smiling" Smiler says at one point which makes this become lazy and incoherent to follow (in case you tried). In short, The Emoji Movie is a faithless; a zestless boilerplate animation which fails in many accesses of its audience and deserves a huge thumb down. VERDICT: An annoying, zestless, tasteless and boring animation which comes with lazy themes and tropes, abandon all hope ye who enter here.
Best movie ever to exist. Watch this before you decide to hate it.

It's no surprise to me that, in today's world, The Emoji Movie is a film that actually exists. Emojis are everywhere thanks to the dependence of smartphones to communicate and it won't be long until it overtakes Chinese, Spanish and English as the most common spoken language in the world. That's not even possible by the way but they'll find a way.Gene (T. J. Miller), a multi-expressional emoji, sets out on a journey to become a normal emoji. There's a little bit more to the plot however, it's not even worth delving further into what this is actually about.Anyone who's ever used a smartphone will be able to tell you that there can be some fun had in using emojis to express yourself, whether it be in an innocent or rude manner. Is it fun to sit through a ninety-minute film about emojis though? The answer is a resounding no.The Emoji Movie is just an excuse for blatant product placement and a chance to make incredibly irrelevant references to popular culture, the Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen song playing as they enter the YouTube app making me want to scream in anger. It's full of insanely annoying characters too, James Corden's Hi-5 being like a turd that just won't flush. You think he's gone but then he makes a very unwanted return.The product as a whole, whether it be the unimaginative animation or the uninspired vocal performances, is void of any likability factor and the fact that I didn't hear one child laugh throughout speaks volumes. Animated films have come on leaps and bounds when it comes to conveying a message to the audience, but not The Emoji Movie. One of the only messages I took from this film was that boys should talk to girls via emojis prior to any form of human interaction. F**k my life.The Emoji Movie is as bad as I thought it'd be and then some. Avoid at all costs.

I'm not going to be as rough on this as the rest of the users on IMdB are (3.5 rating). As a matter of fact, I'll use a character from the movie to describe it. Meh. That's right. There was nothing good or bad about this movie. It just kind unfolded in front of my glazed eyes over the screen. There were a few chuckles, but no laughs. And those who say it's offensive? No. A poop emoji is not offensive. This story stars the emoji misfits Meh, High Five & Hacker on their quest to have lives, and to save themselves from being deleted from the smart phone. They fight against Smiler, who runs the emoji's with an iron "smile", trollers, and malware bots. This movie would have made zero sense less than 20 years ago, and the movie is fading from my memory as I write this review about it. Not exciting, not boring. Save yourself from a "meh" evening.

Since its release in the summer of 2017, The Emoji movie seemed to have caused some sort of uproar from people causing many people to bash it and claiming it as the worst movie ever. A lot of that is highly overreactions. I had little to no expectations considering knowing how low its reviews were and knowing some about the basic of the film.With that said, although the movie is predictable and has a story which has been done before (lead character doesn't feel he belongs, so he sets out on a journey for some kind of redemption, meets a love interest along the way, ends in a happy ending), this is a children's film and for the younger crowd, and since they are familiar with these emojis, it's best not to take the film too serious.Overall, the emoji movie isn't nearly as bad as critics and people are claiming, no it's not a great masterpiece but the visuals and colors are nice looking, and there are some creative product placement. Also the film isn't nearly that long to completely drag on. This movie also made quite a lot at the box office ($217 million worldwide), so people must have enjoyed it to some degree.

This movie is truly a masterpiece that should have entire courses dedicated just to picking apart and deciphering all the intricacies that so wonderfully tie together to make the best film of this generation. When I see the low ratings people give this movie, rather than feeling angry - I feel sorry for these people. I understand why the ratings are so low, not everyone is capable of truly understanding a film as metaphorical and nuanced as this. It isn't your fault if you couldn't comprehend what Tony Leondis was trying to do, but I do hope you begin unpacking your preconceived biases that make you unable to fully understand and enjoy hard hitting queer films like this. Sony truly made history by giving us such a realistic and heartwarming depiction of gender fluidity, and it's obvious that this is something close to their heart as shown by their more recent movie "The Mitchells vs. The Machines" which features a lesbian main character. Sony is taking it upon themselves to bring us the important queer films that other animation studios are too scared to make, it's extremely inspiring. I hope any of you that thought The Emoji Movie was simply a lazy attempt at making money by taking something extremely prevalent in our society (emojis) and throwing in some poop jokes - will try watching it a few more times. Me and my peers regularly get together just to rewatch The Emoji Movie, taking in all the details, oftentimes making lists of new things we didn't notice before - and then we discuss it together, sharing our revelations and the new lesson we've learned (because no matter how many times we watch it - The Emoji Movie somehow manages to teach us something new each time). I'll have to wrap up my review now, lest I go on forever. Though personally, I think of this less as a review and more as a love letter to the greatest film to ever grace our earth, and I urge everyone of you to watch it again with an open mind - it may surprise you.

The Emoji movie its a big joke in the internet, I wish it was just that, an ironic joke made to satirize Hollywood's worst aspects, but no, The Emoji movie is a real movie, and while cash grabs have been present in the past this one got an incredible amount of attention, I guess people just needed something to laugh at seeing how absurd the concept is.I was really annoyed by this movie, every other line was painfully unfunny, there is not one original aspect in it, it rips off many elements from different animated films but doesn't know why they worked, so just decides to copy for no real reason. Every awful clichÃ© from almost any other animated movie is present here, even clichÃ©s that could be considered the weakest parts of good animated films, at least those movies had other redeeming qualities, this one lacks any kind of positive aspect.I do believe that this is the worst of Hollywood, the cynical product placement (The whole movie is one), the awful politics it tries to shove down people's throats, the predictable story, the usual character archetypes we see every time and the evident disconnect it has from its target audience. I don't hate Hollywod but this is one movie not even I would defend.

Having been released in the U.S. a few months ago to a critical mauling, I intended to avoid this animated abomination at all costs. My 7 y.o. daughter, however, had other ideas. Following Gene (T.J. Miller), a malfunctioning 'meh' emoji who can't control his vast range of emotions, we enter the working world of a smartphone whereby every tap of the screen requires a functioning digital population to make it happen. In a universe where everyone (everything?) has its place, Gene is ridiculed for his expressiveness and, after sending out the wrong emoji for his user (Alex, a teenage boy in the midst of his first romance), must go on the run from the delete-happy Smiler (Maya Rudolph). Ostensibly an adventure comedy, there is neither enough thrills to make it exciting or enough laughs to make it amusing; ironically falling into a zone of complete meh-ness. The jokes about twitter, internet trolls and the controlling nature of smartphones in modern society would have been astute a few years ago, in 2017 they're already out-dated and tired. And the target audience for this film wont understand them anyway. Thankfully there are some hilarious visual gags like the poop emoji exiting the toiletÂ… oh wait, nope, even that is old and boring, barely getting a titter from the packed cinema of kids (and parents regretting their choice) ready to laugh at just about anything. The animation is unsurprisingly bright and James Corden's sidekick Hi-5 adds a smidge of delight, however The Emoji Movie ultimately has less flavour and value-for-money than the watered-down soft drink and over-priced popcorn from the cinema's candy bar.

I went to see this movie with my 7-year-old sister. She really enjoyed it! It's the first movie she saw this year where she wanted to stay until the end. I don't know why it's been so harshly criticised; it's lighthearted and funny. I would definitely recommend it for children; they don't analyse the plot like they are some Darth Vader critics. I must say I enjoyed it as well. For anyone who watches it, I hope you enjoy it as much as we did!

There's a lot of hate on this movie and some is not entirely without merit. Actually one of the 1 star reviewer almost got to me, until he mentioned Angry Birds (arguable) but especially the Lego movies. You can't put those in the same bin as this. The Lego movies especially really have a quality to them that speaks to both adults and children. Something this movie does not have.But is it like a disease as some have suggested? I'd say not. I do get the corporate idea thing, that they try to shove into our brain. Let's keep it real though: that always existed. And this movie tries to bank on that. It doesn't really succeed and while it tries to copy a couple of things Pixar and other animated movies did, it never reaches that quality. Having said that, I've seen worse ... and I know that is not an "excuse" for some, concerning my rating, but it's the truth.

...but fails to deliver.Ever since I've seen the trailer for this movie, I've been looking forward to seeing it. The trailer promised so much, but in the end, it was one of those movies that had all the best bits shown in the trailer.The concept for the movie is original and I was expecting the narrative to be another Despicable Me, The Lego Movie, or Wreck It Ralph, level quality. Unfortunately from this reviewer's point of view, it wasn't.The movie has good moments, but they were far and few between to save it from its lowly rating.I tried to like this movie, but with characters that failed to connect with me, and too many try-hard moments, it just disappointed.Anyone older than 12 will probably find this movie tedious.

Maybe it's a symptom of lockdown, but watch a film as shallow and empty as this and find still find some joy.The film is not subtle nor smart in anyway. It is clear that people thought the premise was enough to make the film work and they didn't need to bother with plot, drama or decent jokes.But i still found it just about watchable, which is probably due to the amount of utter rubbish I have already watched in the last year.

This movie is so "bad" that, philosophically, it starts to make you question what makes a "bad" movie, and what the different types of bad are. This movie is probably bad in the worst way possible - it's empty and soulless. This isn't art. This isn't something that tried and missed it's mark. It's a manufactured product using a store-bought just-add-water story. It's the cinematic equivalent of a TV dinner. Now, TV dinners are edible but are they really nourishing? This movie isn't a "failure". The story is fine and complete. But it's soulless.

The Emoji Movie is about Gene the meh emoji and Alex the user of the phone. Alex doesn't know what emoji to send to the girl he likes. Gene how ever has a lot more expressions than meh, and because of that he becomes a outcast and get's banned from Texttown. Now Gene has to try and flee from the robots that are trying to delete him.T.J. Miller plays the voice of Gene and he is absolutely horrible in the movie. Every performance is so bad and I cannot believe that this is a real movie. The screen time is 86 minutes but it feels more like 3 hours. I was not invested in the story at all and of course to make it worse there are two dance sequences in the movie. The animation is flat and boring and has no originality to it.This movie is one of the worst of the year and it is probably the worst animation movie ever made. Don't waste your time on this movie. If I could erase my memory of this movie I absolutely would so just don't watch it I beg you. A movie that is created by some producers with only wanting to make money. DON'T WATCH THIS!!!

Colourful, bright with lovely animation. The story is decent, fairly clichÃ© kids movie, younger kids will probably love it, less so for older kids. The product placement is very, very heavy handed and conspicuous and it's meme attempts are laughably bad. Kids are unlikely to notice, but there's some 'so bad it's good' novelty for the older viewers. Overall it has okay character and message, that even adults can quite enjoy and get somewhat immersed in. It's overall, very OK. I would rate 5 star if it wasn't so ridiculously full of product placement and their 'strong female character' is quite forced. (Seriously, strong women don't need to constantly reassert how strong and independent they are...) The message of this movie? USE DROPBOX PLAY CANDY CRUSH AND DDR AND DID YOU KNOW DROPBOX IS SECURE? Oh, and be yourself and accept everyone for who they are. Gene, the main character is a 'meh emoji, and that reflects the movie. It's just meh.

The lack of pacing and an absolute absence of plot depth made watching this a tiring exercise of patience. When I wasn't cringing at the stupidly unfunny jokes and product placement, I found myself rolling my eyes at the ridiculously predictable dialogue. When I wasn't rolling my eyes, I was desperately checking the running time- which I did about every ten or fifteen minutes. Once it was finally over, I lied face-down on my bed, willing any memories of having watched The Emoji Movie to leave my now much smaller brain. However, I can now live a far happier life knowing that I will never have to subject my ears and eyeballs to this movie again.

I found that this movie worked surprisingly well as a form of discipline. Prior to July 28th, 2017, when my children did something bad, I would punish them by taking away their devices or dessert (you know, the norm). Unfortunately, this method never deemed sufficient, as they would still repeat their actions. However, when my youngest, Timmy, called my oldest, Todd, a "stinky pile of bologna", I knew what I had to do. I marched little Timmy to the car, drove to the nearest cinema, and purchased two tickets to The Emoji Movie. Rest assured, he will never call Todd anything ever again. Or sleep at night. But you know, you have to take the bad with the good.

I'M DONE!!!!! I am sick of how people are saying that the emoji movie is good, it's not! Can't you see the ratings and cringe in this movie? I'm done with Sony!

If I could rank this a "zero" I absolutely would. At least with a movie like "Manos: The Hands of Fate" you KNOW someone tried their hardest and you can somewhat appreciate that. There is not one second of consideration put into any frame of this film. Every character is bland, every design is generic, every joke and plot thread is predictable.It's a desperate and I do mean desperate attempt to capitalize on a growing and recent trend. It's a money-grabber to say the least. You take a subject popular with young kids, you get paid by a bunch of different companies to display their terrible apps in the movie, etc, etc. This movie had no passion. Movies are made to make money but they are typically a labour of love. Most directors put their heart and souls into their films, while clearly no one cared about this one.I feel bad for Patrick Stewart. Please do not give one cent to the makers of this movie.

The Emoji Movie is an exciting adventure with memorable characters and complete with hilarious jokes and clever themes! Oh... sorry... that's what you WISH it was. This movie is so unbelievably terrible that Sony had to put SO much effort into Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse just to make up for this piece of Sir Patrick Stewart, who, by the way, plays a poop emoji. That's pretty much the movie in a nutshell. But if you want a more extensive answer, the movie is, boring, the characters are, forgettable, the script is, awful, the jokes are, cringe-worthy, the premise is, beyond stupid, the animation is, just OK, and the less I say about the bucket-load of product placement, the better. This may just be the worst animated movie of all time.

The Emoji Movie is poorly written and the jokes are unfunny. This doesn't deserve to be a masterpiece out of almost every single animated movie. I don't really recommend watching this pile of trash because of how stupid, how unfunny, how boring, and how unenjoyable it is. Plot kinda lacks about why this movie is about emojis, and somehow the movie plagarized ideas from other movies I liked, such as The LEGO Movie, Wreck it Ralph, and Inside Out. Basically I'll explain more here. So basically about Gene and his friends setting his journey to go on an app adventures? That literally doesn't pretty mean about why this movie is about emojis. In the other hand, Jailbreak, the tritagonist of the movie, is nothing but a ripoff of Wyldstyle from The LEGO Movie. Smiler, the antagonist of the movie, her design makes it an uncanny valley to it, making it pretty creepy. The story itself, is really boring and unenjoyable. In the other hand, really bland and confusing to understand about (especially bland and confusing about why this movie is about emojis). So there you have it, The Emoji Movie is what people definitely didn't enjoy and ask for.Overall, this movie deserves to get a D-Movies like The LEGO Movie, Wreck it Ralph, Inside Out, Spider-verse, the upcoming Super Mario Bros. Movie coming out in April 7, 2023, and Smurfs: The Lost Village (the Sony pictures animation film that preceded this trash movie, even though this doesn't mean I hate this Smurfs movie) are better in general than this piece of coal.

Everybody should watch this movie.

It has become a meme of how bad this movie is. After watching it I feel that it was not so bad.
The movie is basically Wreck-it Ralph meets Inside-Out. Those movies are hardly masterpieces to begin with, and to me their biggest quality was their high-concept premise. Wreck-it Ralph is already an adaptation of Toy Story but with video games and Inside Out is too transparent with its emotional arcs.
Anyway, that leaves us with a movie that does not have an original premise, does not have a visually unique aesthetic and has a very linear story. Yet, I did not hate this film. Is it boring? Yes definitely, but mostly because a lot of what it does I have already seen before. However, for younger audiences that have not seen a lot of movie this might not be an issue.Other than that, the movie suffers from flaws that are independent from the movie itself. These are problems that affect larger movies, and that have nothing to do with the story or the way it is told. For instance, the fact that every character is voiced by a celebrity. The omnipresent use of product placement or references to real life brands. It distracted me constantly. These things are not necessarily bad, and if you don't know what Dropbox or Spotify is, then you're fine. But for me, it made it harder to invest myself in the movie's universe. You cannot get lost if everything you see is recognisable.A positive thing that I will give the movie credit for, is that it makes good use of the emojis themselves. There is enough variety to make it interesting, even if it is not particularly inspired. (in other words it is rather "meh" (I'm so sorry))
Visually, the animations are well done. Technically the film holds up. That is why I do not understand the sheer hate this movie gets. It might be lazy sure, but it is not necessarily incompetent.That being said there was one sequence that irked me a little, when James Corden declares "you don't need real friends but you only need fans that give you unrelenting support as long as you are on top". This sequence, which revolves around being an ad for Facebook, goes totally unchallenged by the characters or the narrative, and it is rather strange message for a movie aimed at kids that might not grasp all the nuances and caveats of social media.Overall, the movie is heavily flawed and uninspired. Yet, I don't feel that it is dramatically different from any other modern children oriented animated movies. When compared to Wreck-it Ralph or Inside-Out, the former is saved by its love for video games and the latter works on the human story level, not so much on the heavy-handed metaphor. The emojis are not an old tradition with a passionate subculture and the over-arching story of the teen getting his phone wiped is not especially riveting. But there is fancy colours.

The Emoji Movie attempts to tell the story of a "meh" emoji named Gene, who lives in the digital world inside a smartphone. Unlike the other emojis, Gene has multiple emotions, and this disrupts the functioning of the phone's messaging system. As he tries to become "normal," he goes on a journey with other emojis like Hi-5 and a hacker emoji named Jailbreak.\:Animation quality: The visuals are clean and polished. Sony Pictures Animation is technically capable, and the digital environments are bright and colorful.Voice talent: The cast includes T. J. Miller, James Corden, Anna Faris, and Patrick Stewart (voicing the poop emoji), though their talent is mostly wasted here.Story: The narrative is generic and heavily derivative of better films It lacks originality and emotional depth.Characters: Most characters are one-dimensional, driven by clichÃ©s rather than genuine personality. Their development is shallow and unengaging.Product placement: The movie aggressively promotes real apps (e.g. Spotify, Dropbox, Candy Crush) in ways that feel forced and commercial rather than natural parts of the story.Tone and humor: Much of the humor is juvenile, relying on puns and emoji-related jokes that feel dated and uninspired even for a young audience.The message about self-acceptance is clumsily delivered, buried under a pile of digital metaphors that feel hollow.

If cinema is a language, The Emoji Movie speaks in grunts and typos. This 2017 animated film attempts to surf the wave of smartphone culture, but instead belly flops into a sea of product placement, lazy writing, and cynical pandering.Set inside a teenager's phone (because apparently, that's where stories live now), the film follows Gene, a "meh" emoji who's just too expressive for his own good. It's a premise that could have explored identity or digital culture with some charm or depth. Instead, it offers an exhausting barrage of corporate cameos; from Candy Crush to Dropbox, as if the film were more interested in brand partnerships than making a story.The animation is competent, but sterile. Characters are uninspired both visually and emotionally, reduced to one-note caricatures based on whatever app or emoji they represent. The humor is low-effort and rarely lands, aiming squarely at the youngest of audiences but insulting even their intelligence. A poop joke voiced by Sir Patrick Stewart should be funny in theory. In practice, it just feels like a career dare.There's a faint attempt at a moral; something about being yourself, but it's buried under layers of buzzwords and bland storytelling. By the time the credits roll, you're left wondering not just why this movie was made, but why you watched it.The Emoji Movie isn't offensively bad, it's just depressingly mediocre. A 90-minute advertisement disguised as a film. Save your bandwidth and your money. Watch literally anything else.

After the secret life of your toys, the secret life of insects, the secret world of monsters under your bed, and the patently ridiculous secret world inside your brain, is it so surprising that some brain-dead executives would attempt 'the secret world inside your phone'? More kids these days care about phones than toys or their own brain, so wouldn't that make it more *important*? All those people who praised 'Inside Out' to the skies are to blame for this monstrosity of a movie, and the Emoji Movie is the next logical step for hooey children's entertainment.

I'm utterly baffled about who is the intended audience for this film. It is probably meant for younger viewers but it clearly looks down on modern youth as easily impressionable, simple minded and not tech savvy. Are they trying to appeal to youth or insult them? Any modern child or teen can see through this stereotype and the relentless technical inaccuracies. I had some concerns that all the hate for this movie was founded, but I have found that a lot of either box-office bombs or hated movies or both are actually better than people make out (with the exception of The Adventures of Scooter the Penguin), so I decided that I would give it a go.
Now, this is by far the most unoriginal movie ever - it's general plot, themes, and stuff are all stuff that we've seen time and time again.
It has some of the cheesiest lines in history (with Aquaman coming in a close second).
It is also extremely predictable.
But it has a talented cast who's voices are just perfect for their roles, great animation, and you know what? It doesn't hurt to hear the message that this movie showcases once again as it is actually relevant.
And while it is predictable it also is entertaining enough to keep you interested. Though, if you don't like the plot, give it a shot for the music. The music in it is fantastic, even if you don't like the plot.
It's meant to be a funny, feel-good, charming movie greatly succeeds in that regard.
Give it a shot, though I can't guarantee whether or not you'd like it.

Why am I watching The Emoji Movie in the year 2025? Well I was curious to see if it was really as bad as it's dirt-like reputation suggests.I'm happy to report that it was indeed quite bad. The Emoji Movie (2017) takes elements of Wreck-It Ralph (2012), The Lego Movie (2014), and a dash of Inside Out (2015) and yet fails to recreate the magic that any of those other three films have. It's a movie that seems flawed from the very concept. This is a movie with jokes more geared towards children, but with a subject matter (tech, texting, social media) more geared towards teens and adults.The movie is just hollow and soulless, absolutely no heart to be found. All it ends up being is bland pop culture references followed by already aged poorly, product placement.Was the Emoji pop dance meant to be an attempt to create a viral trend? I hope not, what a tremendous failure. Speaking of which, who plays Just Dance on their phone? I could be wrong, but I've never heard of that.Apparently, this movie was the first shown in theaters in Saudi Arabia after a 35-year ban was lifted. I think that perfectly describes this film's target audience; people who haven't seen a movie in 35 years.I rate this three poop Emojis out of ten.

Sony Pictures Animation is fast becoming a nuisance studio, responsible for the most needless and abhorrent animated features known to man. In 2017 alone, The Star and now The Emoji Movie headlines this studio's filmography, succumbing to new levels of BOGUS per offering. TSK.This Emoji Movie is bogged down by concepts that are absolutely pointless and even reaches levels of depressing. The universe the picture pushes for is DEJECTING, with lore that's centered around product placement over adventure, and character motivations that are excruciatingly shallow. Imagine a grand finale centered on Dropbox, consequential exploits around Candy Crush and Just Dance and character incentive to be Meh. MEH?! Also, its narrative that attempts at connecting real world drama to its fantastical beats comes off insanely weak and out of place, with coming of age messages that screams fakery. Its brand of humor is as well uninventive & bland, and with the absence of interesting characters, entertainment value isn't even this blunder's saving grace.Overall, The Emoji Movie has NO REASON TO EXIST. We do not need gimmicks around phones as it is impossible to create a captivating universe, centered on money-grabbing platforms. With this premise, it as well a challenge to believe storylines that boasts of upsides to real world connections. BOGUS!

As it's one of the worst animated movies ever made, The Emoji Movie is also possibly the worst animated movie to be produced by a mainstream animation studio. This is an example of how Hollywood can sometimes be lazy, and pile all these issues into one horrible film. The writing is at its worst, the story has no originality whatsoever, the animation is terribly executed, the jokes are an embarrassment, the message coming from this movie feels outdated, the characters are all a bunch of jerks, the voice actors didn't even try, and the entire world building is the high definition of cringe. Everybody do me one favor: If you want to keep your sanity, don't watch this movie at all. Don't even show this to kids in general. Very justifiable to win a razzie, but I also believing in deleting this movie permanently.

"Emoji" is a film that revolves around the world of emojis and attempts to create a story from it. Unfortunately, the film falls flat.The film's plot is shallow and predictable, lacking creative ideas and a compelling story to engage the audience. Instead, it feels like a marketing ploy to capitalize on the popularity of emojis.The characters are one-dimensional and clichÃ©d, offering little development or opportunities for the audience to connect with them. The dialogue is uninspired and at times even frustrating, lacking genuine substance and originality.The animation in the film is technically competent, but that alone cannot compensate for the lack of quality and substance. It seems that the film primarily aims to attract young viewers with colorful visuals rather than tell a captivating story.The jokes and humor in the film are flat and forced, with few genuinely funny moments to make the audience laugh. Instead, it relies on tired clichÃ©s and wordplay that quickly become tiresome.Overall, "Emoji" deserves a rating of 1/10. The film disappoints on many levels, offering little that makes it worth watching. It lacks a compelling plot, well-developed characters, and original humor. For anyone looking for a quality film, "Emoji" is definitely not recommended.

First and foremost, the plot is as thin as the phone screen it's projected onto. We follow the adventures of Gene, a "Meh" emoji who can't quite conform to his one-dimensional role. The whole journey to become "normal" is as clichÃ©d as they come, and it feels like a missed opportunity to explore more interesting themes in the digital age.The characters are as one-dimensional as the emojis themselves, lacking depth or relatability. Even the talented voice cast, including T. J. Miller and James Corden, can't salvage the lackluster writing and character development. The jokes and gags are mostly cringe-worthy, relying heavily on outdated internet culture references that will leave most viewers scratching their heads.Visually, it's colorful and occasionally fun, but it doesn't make up for the movie's shortcomings. The attempt to turn smartphone apps and the digital world into a tangible universe falls flat, leaving the audience with a sense of disconnection rather than immersion.Perhaps the most frustrating aspect of "The Emoji Movie" is its transparent attempt to capitalize on the popularity of emojis and smartphones, making it feel like a shameless cash grab rather than a genuine attempt at storytelling. It's hard to shake the feeling that this movie was made solely to sell merchandise and capitalize on a trendy concept. First and foremost, the plot is as thin as the phone screen it's projected onto. I've never really been a big fan of Sony, except for Spider Man: Into the Spider Verse and the Spider Man franchise with Tom Holland as Spider Man. These ones are really good. But THIS? Not really.First, I don't like how the kids in this movie are portrayed as being only devoted to their phones. Many kids value more IMPORTANT things than phones and screens, like their education and their family. That stereotype is an insult to kids, and the kids who see that will not want to watch this. The plot and characters were very, very bland, (it IS about EMOJIS, after all), and the dialogue is just plain bad. This movie has been stuck in my head ever since I made the terrible mistake seeing this in theaters a few years ago. This movie is annoying and pointless. It has poor storytelling and is a mix of cliches from other movies. It's nothing but a cash grab advertisement and one of Sony's biggest mistakes yet.I haven't watched this for a long time, and I'm grateful. For all you lucky people who haven't seen this stupidity, then DON'T. The Emoji Movie is not worth your time at all. Don't even bother renting it.

It's not the best but I feel like it's overhated. Although a lot of the aspects are heavily based around appealing to the youth and being trendy the movie as a whole wasn't that cringe. Some of the scenes were a little funny and smile is definitely one of the most entertaining characters in the movie. The story theme is somewhat generic basically being "be yourself". Giving emojis depth was probably a challenge but i think they did alright, though they could have done better for some characters. The comedy in the movie could have been better cause some of the jokes and puns are forced but the unintentional funny parts werethe best. The movie is very formulaic and does lack creativity in a lot of areas. It's definitely not 3/10 but 5.3/10 seems reasonable, if you enjoy 3d animation movies or like Pixar movies you'll like this movie. Edit: Hand emoji was probably the worst.

So this isn't a great movie..but it's a film about Emojis for kids so surely you can't go into it expecting an animated equivalent of Citizen Kane.For some reason my 5yr old likes this film so I have been subjected to it on a fairly regular basis. It's bright, it's colourful and a bit of fun. I don't think it's much worse than some of the other terrible films of a similar kind and if you just take it for what it is then it isn't that bad.It would appear the writers have been given the Emoji brief and have had to create what they can within this limited world. There are some decent lines in it and some interesting uses of the subject of smart phones. The voice over performances are decent and I'm sure if you look deep enough I'm sure there is a moral to the story.

This is the most boring movie i have ever watched. Jokes were for 3 year olds, story was very stupid, characters were bland and lacking depth, the settings of the film were very unthoughtful, and half of the movie was pure cringe. Even the music was depressing. It's like the producers fell asleep on their jobs... They also clearly rushed it, yet they had years to make this movie. Marvel had the same time as them and how come they did a better job? This movie had only an hour and 20 minutes in screen time. That is basically a little less than half of a normal movie. It should be in the "animated shorts" section, to make sure nobody watches it. So if you want to waste a short amount of time making fun of a crappy of a movie, then do so. If not, dont waste your time, your eyes will bleed. Only watch it and make fun of it when you can watch it illegally on some Youtube channel before it gets shut down.

I expected the movie to be actual garbage. I wanted the movie to suck, but it's actually not terrible. Of course it has its flaws, and the idea of the movie is kind of boring. The story isn't terrible, and the animation is very smooth and looks nice. There are some moments that made me go "what?", which include two sentences that made no sense to the story. All in all i rate the movie 5 stars.

Makes me want to scratch my eyes out until they bleed and yell, "EWWWWWWW!!!! WHAT IS THAT THING?!" Disgusting and utterly terrible garbage! Never even seeing this movie again! 0 out of 10 would not recommend.

The Emoji Movie.... Man I watched this last year and this was so bad that I literally had to do a full on Instagram story like thing of me watching this movie and it took all of my strength to make it through this movie.Luckily, Sony made a better animated film in 2018 with "Into the SpiderVerse", a movie I wasn't even that excited for until I found out who was involved in it and later trailers and it was miles better than this.The only saving graces I have is the animation and the voice acting but my god, the product placement is OBNOXIOUS AS ALL KINDS OF HECK and this movie is so unoriginal, not funny, boring, lame and frustratingly awful. The Candy Crush thing? WHAT THE HECK WE'RE THE FILMMAKERS THINKING WHEN THEY WROTE THIS MOVIE OR PUT THIS INTO PRODUCTION?!!The only thing product placement wise that I didn't mind were YouTube and somewhat, Just Dance, but that isn't enough. And why is there a Star Trek reference in here? The only thing this got out of me was a few chuckles because I couldn't believe my eyes.If i had sat through this back in 2017, this would've made my worst films of the year.Grade: JD GOMFC (Get out of my face, Emoji Movie)THIS MADE MORE MONEY THAN BLADE RUNNER 2049! SOMEHOW!!
Terrible idea, terrible execution.A movie about emojis? Really? Sounds like a stupid idea that was mostly made to get with the "trends".The writing is awful, and it is just a bad movie.

Sony has had some bad movies before but Jebus... The Emoji movie is the biggest slap in the face to millennials I have ever seen. This "movie" (if you could even call it that), is the downfall to 2017 and the world as we know it. The biggest cinematic flop in history is the Emoji movie. It was only created to make money by greedy, worthless, talent less imbeciles, and they succeeded all to well. Shameless product placement and 'trendy' voice actors worked. And to put the icing on this big stinking pile, it was marketed towards kids. The Emoji Movie may seem harmless enough, but when you take a closer look, its just a barbaric marketing scheme that worked out in Sony's favor. So whatever you do, DON'T TAKE YOU KIDS TO THIS GOD FORSAKEN, GARBAGE HEAP OF A FILM!

I was dreading my kid wanting to watch this because I had heard how bad it was. I heard that it was so awful, the worst kids movie ever, unbearable, etc. I managed to let my son forget about it while it was theaters and felt like I had dogged a bullet. When it came out on Netflix, I begrudgingly let him watch it. It's not that bad! Really, it's not. Would I recommend it to my friends and their kids? Not in particular. Is it insightful and clever? No. But is it a terribly bad movie? Also no. Kids (about age 8 and under probably) will be entertained and adults may be mildly amused at a few of the jokes. Anna Farris was really cute as the Jailbreak character and High-Five, while slightly obnoxious at times, was actually pretty funny. The plot has a few logistical problems, but most all movies do. And it's a kids movie; they don't really care about that stuff. Their standards aren't that high. 
So overall, it's FINE. Doesn't deserve all the hate.
The storyline is a cliche, but I still liked it. I really liked HI-5 with his annoying character and they cast a great voice for smiler! It was okay to watch, but I will not watch it again.
I thought this would be a so bad it was kind of good situation, but na. Just plain bad, bad, bad.

It's not down right awful... just meh.For starters, yes, this movie is not good. Awful story followed by awful characters. The movie is always being dumb or stupid every 10 seconds that you can't help but laugh at how badly this can get.They also never use the concept of a phone great. A fire wall as an actual Fire Wall! Where does that fit?I don't hate it, it's still watchable for the first 15-20mins before it starts becoming unbearable. Adding in a forced romance?! Not every movie needs the main character falling in love with the girl character!Yes it's bad to meh. But, not as bad as some say, but still not good, + Very Cringy and Corny!

I saw this in theaters once. Me and my dad thought it was okay from what I remember. I thought the hate might've been overexaggerated but I guess I was wrong. Personally, I think that Barbie (2023) was way worse than this. As the movie was more childish and that it is very overly peppy despite that movie has a PG-13 with a ridiculous premise.

I wasn't expecting much when my daughter randomly put this on over the Christmas holiday, but good grief was this film derivative. The Emoji Movie follows the 'meh' emoji as he goes to his first day at work inside some kids phone. Thing is, he actually has the ability to be pretty much any emoji, and when he freaks out while the kid is texting, the kid thinks there is something wrong with his phone. Hence, the phone gets booked in for a service, and all the characters in the phone start freaking out, thinking they will all be deleted and reset. So its up to Meh to put things right...If that all sounds very, well, 'meh'... then congratulations - you have probably seen one of the many, many MANY similar animated movies with this identical plot arc. Guy causes issue endangering everyone so has to go on a quest of personal discovery to fix it. Meh. The whole film just felt specifically like an Inside Out ripoff, but worse in every way. I mean, even my 11yo daughter turned to me about 3/4 the way through and said "this is a bit cr*p isn't it?" Yes, yes it is. It is, in fact, fittingly, very 'meh' (ok I'll stop making that joke now). Just don't waste your time, there are hundreds of better animated films out there...

Is the first animated Razzie Award winner The Emoji Movie the worst film of the year? Gene (T.J. Miller) is a 'meh' emoji inside a kid's iPhone who wants to be a wide variety of expressions. Once he accidentally glitches the phone, he crosses the threshold and exits Textropolis with his band of misfits Hi-5 (James Corden) and Jailbreak (Anna Faris), going through all sorts of Apps like CandyCrush, Just Dance, Spotify, and Dropbox, to escape from the bots hired by Smiler (Maya Rudolph). The obvious message in the film is that technology connects people together, so buy an iPhone and text an emoji to show your love for another. Hearing that flimsy and gimmicky moral, I saw The Emoji Movie as a 90-minute commercial for Sony products, with all the features installed such as a half-baked story, uninspired characters, and obnoxious puns, but colorful imaginative worlds. As for Alex, the phone's owner who sends a text to let go of his comfort zone, he is no Riley from Inside Out. The boy is just as dreadfully boring as all the other phone-ridden schoolmates, including his girl crush, and the apps and emojis don't do much to support his character arc. Also, the film missed an opportunity to have the emojis escape the phone world and enter the WiFi network, where they might accidentally damage the system causing chaos in not just the school but the world. This could have been a unique children's satire tackling the impact of technology among humans. However, The Emoji Movie and Sony exist to only advertise trendy electronics rather than glorifying the art of cinema. (1 Â½ Thumbs Down Symbols out of 5)

Movie was enjoyable if your a 5 year old. James Corden deserves better than to play a thumb in a stupid movie that's for kids under 5. It wasn't God awful but it seemed like it would be a Nickelodeon movie that never went in the theaters. If I could describe it with one emoji. THUMB DOWN!

The idea behind this movie is just ridiculous. The execution was just worse and the humor was just terrible. Pls. Don't watch this movie and don't trust the 10 star reviews. It is not worth it and watching paint dry is way funner than watching this... thing.

This film is a very, very bad film. The product placement on this film is straight up ridiculous. Also, the idea itself is terrible. How can you build a good and genuine world around EMOJIS??? Yeah, you can't, because they are so simple and generic, that it be pointless trying. Yet Sony tried, and obviously failed at trying. Also, the actual story itself is also really bad. It's also so forgettable that I already forgot what this movie was about. What I remember is that it's about this really badly structured main character, named Gene, who is supposedly to be a "Meh" emoji. But instead, he does a giant variety of emotions. That's all you need to know about the story, anyways, bye,

Some Hollywood exec thought it would be a good idea to base an entire movie on the emojis on your phone. Oh and Candy Crush features because you know...it's also on your phone. Was it a dry period for ideas? Was this thought up by someone sitting on the toilet?So they're absolutely stretching it as a concept as it is - but then add a terrible, obvious plot and that uber turd James Corden as a voice actor (seriously Hollywood there are other British people out there!) and you've got one of the worst animated movies of all time.I'm seriously hoping someone lost their job over this one, just ridiculously bad.

The emoji movie is a feature length commercial literally about emojis. The "film" has even more product placement than an Adam sander film. The only positive about this movie was that the animation is actually pretty nice, but other from that don't waste your money on a commercial. And don't say that just because the film is essentially a feature length commercial that it can't be good, because the LEGO movie was all about product placement, and that was an animated masterpiece.

I rate this movie 10/10 because it destroys your brain cells and you will thoroughly enjoy. Best movie if you are looking to tarnish your sanity. Nobody likes this movie but it is amazing and definitely recommend to you and not kids unless you want them to be stupid for the rest of their live. Long story short watch this movie. Please.

The only thing this movie truly has it going for is the (insultingly) beautiful animation. The visuals are stunning, everything is bright and colorful (for a kids movie, at least), and the emoji designs... are not really that bad.With that being said, watching this movie from start to finish was THOROUGHLY unenjoyable. The writing was some of the worst I've ever seen, the screenplay is horrible, the plot is bland & repetitive, the characters are annoying/forgettable, and the humor.. my god, the humor. The only, and I mean the ONLY times I've at least had a smile on my face was right at the beginning where we see that that the text emoticons are considered the elderly in their universe, and the Just Dance scene, as I love Just Dance. Also, what is with this movie and playing "Feel This Moment" by Pitbull and Christina Aguilera twice? I personally love the song but man, why couldn't they just pick a different song for the end?Overall, this movie really IS as bad as everyone said it was back in 2017. Don't show this to your kid(s). Show them Wreck-It-Ralph, The Lego Movie, or Inside Out instead. They'll have way more fun watching those movies instead of this boring mess.

Excruciatingly bad. It's proper rubbish.Based on the reputation of this, I knew it was going to be utter tripe. I always wait to watch myself to form my own opinion, but there is no doubt about it - 'The Emoji Movie' is truly awful. It's such a lazy attempt, there is absolutely no creativity and there doesn't seem to have been that much care put into this. How about that product placement, also?!I will say I do like the idea, you could probably create a fine film with it. However, man did they get the execution incredibly wrong. That's also not good given the cast performances, all of which are quite pathetic. In fairness, they don't exactly get much to work with.I'm someone who likes James Corden, but he is terrible here. As is T.J. Miller, while Anna Faris and Maya Rudolph are forgettable. I was disappointed (sorta) not to see more of Patrick Stewart's character, given how much I've heard in recent years; he's barely in it.It's a painful watch, even with a run time of just 86 minutes.
This movie was nothing compared to the other movies I have seen in my past. I would rather watch them then this movie! So, this movie sucks and I recommend nobody to watch it.
It came, it made more then the budget and left a sour taste in everyone's mouth after watching it, awful movie.

There's not much to say past the title I have for this. It's a copy of better films, it takes time to go over how to play games on your phone at the time, the human characters are blank slates, and the jokes are easily seen from a mile away. I do believe there is a better version of the film that could've been made if the people were given the time to flesh out the story better and if the studio wasn't constantly interfering with development. Otherwise, just avoid having your kids watch this in favor of something better, they deserve it.

This movie is the Meh emoji, and how he has a lot of other expressions besides: Meh.I watched this movie with zero expectations, this movie is a product placement piece of trash, the moral of this movie is text more! And it's terrible, it's just SO bad.

What a ðŸ’© movie. This is the ultimate in lazy, committee led film making typical of what you get when a bunch of grey suits try to cash in on the latest trend but lack any form of creative vision. The story is as generic as you can get with no thought put into it whatsoever. It feels like it was cobbled together in an afternoon with some lazy and unfunny pop culture references thrown in and then never looked at again. The voice acting doesn't fare much better with the feeling that the actors showed up, read the lines in the tone on the prompt and went home, everything is just so flat and emotionless. The animation is the only part that seems to have had any effort put into it and even that falls way below the standards of most modern computer animated films.The only positive is that James Corden's character spends some time in the deleted items bin, something I wish would happen in real life only on a more permanent basis.

I kept hearing how bad this movie was but wanted to see it for myself. Although it was cringey and cliche I actually enjoyed it. It started off rough but the ending was good. My nieces and nephews thought it was ok and that's all that really matters since it's targeted to kids.

The Emoji Movie is not good. Let's get that right out of the way. But I think it's notable for paving the way for a much more beloved recent film, Ralph Breaks the Internet. The plot and tone of each film is incredibly similar but the latter had the Disney princesses wearing sweatpants so everyone thought that was good and this was really bad? In reality, both films are scrounging at the bottom of the barrel as far as kids flicks go. I can't totally pan either one because they, unfortunately, both kept my daughter's attention to varying degrees. The bar is low. Sorry, sweatpants princesses. Ideally, one would stay away from both of these on the general principle that they--apart from trying to ruin your brain with their maddeningly fast-paced content--they fall prey to being straight-up, pro-consumerist garbage. The Emoji Movie is honestly probably more annoying than Wreck-It Ralph 2 but because it's premise is, by default, more original, I would give it the slight nod as far as my recommendations go.

First of all, I must note, while watching this movie (of the which back tracks at the very least 30 years in human development) my poor dying grandmother infested with diseases beyond comprehension started gasping for the air of life. I looked for the source of these gurgled releases of air from her ill-ridden lungs and soon realized the ailments's originality had been due to the movie's magical terribleness. Also because gramps unplugged the CPAP, but I'm certain- nay- positive, that this movie was the cause grammy's early demise.
I don't understand all the poor reviews, this film was creative and innovative from a new perspective: building a whole world around a small tech feature
